In addition, each estimator depends on the number of equal-sized folds $K$ in which the data is randomly split. In what follows, I present and discuss the recommendations for implementing DML, including how to select $K$.

First lesson: DML2 is the recommended option for implementing DML, especially in small-sample situations when increasing the number of folds is desired to improve the precision of the estimators $\hat{\eta}_{k}(\cdot)$, which use a fraction $(K-1) / K$ of the sample size $n$. This recommendation is not new -it was presented in Chernozhukov et al. (2018)—, but now it has a theoretical justification in terms of bias and MSE. Results in Section 3.2 show that the asymptotic distribution of DML2 is insensitive in terms of bias and MSE to the values of $K$, which is not the case of DML1 -which becomes increasingly sensitive in terms of bias and MSE to large values of $K$ whenever the discrepancy measure $\Lambda$-defined in (3.6)— deviates from zero. Moreover, the conditions presented in Section 3.1 guarantee that estimators based on DML2 are asymptotically valid for any $K \leq n$, including the leave-one-out estimator defined as DML2 with $K=n$.

## Number of Folds for Cross-Fitting

The previous lesson recommends the use of DML2 estimators, but it is not clear how to choose the number of folds since the results of Section 3.2 show that all DML2 estimators share the same asymptotic distribution. This question is addressed in what follows by considering two

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Higher-order bias for DML2, where $n=1,000, F=1$, and $\varphi=2 / 5$.
different criterion based on the (higher-order) asymptotic bias and the second-order MSE. I use the explicit formulas presented in Section 3.3, where the higher-order properties of DML2 estimators were studied when $K$ is fixed or increases with the sample size $n$.

Second lesson: Choosing the number of folds equal to the sample size to implement DML2 is asymptotically optimal to reduce the (higher-order) asymptotic bias. The explicit formulas presented in Section 3.3 show that the absolute value of the leading term of the higher-order asymptotic bias for DML2 estimators is decreasing on $K$. For convenience, this explicit formula is presented next,

$$
\left|F_{\delta}+F_{b}\right|\left(1+\frac{1}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi} n^{-2 \varphi}
$$

where $\varphi \in(1 / 4,1 / 2)$. Figure 1 presents this explicit formula scaled by $\sqrt{n}$ as a function of the number of folds $K$, which appears as a blue line with circular markers, and the optimal level (minimal) obtained when $K=n$, which appears as a constant red line with square markers. Figure 1 uses $n=1,000, F=1$ and $\varphi=2 / 5$ for illustrative purposes.

Therefore, choosing $K=n$ to implement DML2 is optimal to reduce the asymptotic bias, while the common recommendations of choosing $K=5,10$ or 20 is suboptimal. Finally, Figure 1 reveals that the discrepancy between the asymptotic bias with the common recommendations for $K$ and the optimal choice can be small. However, this conclusion may depend on the values of $n, F$, and $\varphi$ that Figure 1 is using. In the fourth lesson, I discuss the relative loss of the asymptotic bias with respect to the optimal choice for the common choice of $K$ for arbitrary values of $F$ and $\varphi$.

Third lesson: Choosing the number of folds equal to the sample size to implement DML2 can be asymptotically optimal to reduce the second-order asymptotic MSE. In other words, the leave-one-estimator defined as the DML2 estimator using $K=n$ can be the

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2: Second-order MSE for DML2, where $n=1,000, \sigma=1, G_{b}=1$, and $\varphi=2 / 5$.
most asymptotically accurate estimator among the class of DML2 estimators when a certain data-dependent condition holds.

To illustrate this lesson, I present next the second-order asymptotic MSE when the variance and the bias of the nuisance parameter estimator have the same convergence rate (i.e., $\varphi=\varphi_{1}=\varphi_{2}$ ), that is

$$
\text { SO-MSE of } \hat{\theta}_{n, 2}=\sigma^{2} / n+G_{b}\left(1+\frac{1}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi-1 / 2} / n^{1 / 2+2 \varphi}
$$

where $\varphi \in(0,1 / 2)$ and $G_{b}$ is a complex object that depends on the data. Note that SO-MSE of $\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}$ in (4.2) is a decreasing function of $K$ whenever $G_{b}$ is positive, which is the data-dependent condition mentioned above. Figure 2 presents the second-order MSE scaled by $n$ as a function of the number of folds $K$, which appears as a blue line with circular markers, and the optimal second-order MSE obtained by $K=n$ (under the assumption that $G_{b}>0$ ), which appears as a constant red line with square markers. Figure 2 uses $n=1,000$, $\sigma=1, G_{b}=1$, and $\varphi=2 / 5$ for illustrative purposes.

Therefore, choosing $K=n$ to implement DML2 is optimal to reduce the second-order MSE, while the common recommendations of $K=5,10$, or 20 are suboptimal under this criterion. Finally, the relative loss of the second-order MSE with respect to the optimal choice looks small for $K \geq 10$. However, a general conclusion may depend on the values of the parameters $\left(n, \sigma, G_{b}, \varphi\right)$. In the fourth lesson, I discuss the relative loss of the secondorder asymptptoc MSE with respect to the optimal choice for the common choice of $K$ for arbitrary values of the parameters used in Figure 2.

Remark 4.1. Figure 2 -and more concretely, the explicit expression for the second-order MSE presented in (4.2)— explains several of the findings obtained through simulations, such

as the relatively large gains in accuracy by increasing $K$ from 2 to 5 folds in comprising with increasing $K$ from 5 to 10 or 10 to 20 .

The previous two lessons reveal that the common recommendation of choosing 5,10 , or 20 folds for the cross-fitting procedure in DML (e.g., Ahrens et al. (2024a,b), Bach et al. (2022), and Bach et al. (2024)) is suboptimal in terms of (higher-order) bias and second-order MSE. In the next lesson, I will discuss the relative loss a practitioner can face by choosing $K=5,10,20$ instead of the optimal choice $K=n$.

Fourth lesson: If the optimal choice in terms of bias and accuracy is $K=n$, then choosing $K=10$ to implement DML2 guarantees that the maximum relative loss with respect to the optimal choice in terms of bias and second-order MSE is around $10 \%$ and $5 \%$, respectively. In other words, the practitioner implementing DML2 with $K=10$ has an estimator with a (higher-order) bias that is at most $10 \%$ larger than the bias obtained by implementing DML2 with the optimal $K=n$. Similarly, the second-order MSE of the DML2 estimator with $K=10$ is at most $5 \%$ larger than the one obtained by implementing DML2 with the optimal $K=n$. In what follows, I explain in more detail these results and present simple expressions to calculate these maximum relative losses as a function of $K, n$, and $\varphi$.

The relative loss of the (higher-order) bias with respect to the optimal choice is presented next as a function of $K$,

$$
\left(\frac{1+\frac{1}{K-1}}{1+\frac{1}{n-1}}\right)^{2 \varphi}-1
$$

which represents the percentage change of (4.1) with respect to the optimal value of (4.1) $(K=n)$. Panel (a) in Figure 3 presents the previous expression in percentages as a function of $K$. The blue line with circular markers represents the case of nuisance function estimators with slower convergence rates $(\varphi=1 / 4)$, while the red line with square markers corresponds to nuisance function estimators with faster convergence rates $(\varphi=1 / 2)$. It follows from (4.3) and the figure that when $K=10$, the relative loss of the (higher-order) bias is between $5 \%$ and $10 \%$ for different values of $\varphi \in(1 / 4,1 / 2)$; therefore, it is at most $10 \%$. Figure 3 considered $n=1,000$; nevertheless, the results do not change whenever $n \geq 1,000$.

The relative loss of the second-order MSE with respect to the optimal choice is presented next as a function of $K$,

$$
\frac{1+v\left(1+\frac{1}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi-1 / 2} / n^{2 \varphi-1 / 2}}{1+v\left(1+\frac{1}{n-1}\right)^{2 \varphi-1 / 2} / n^{2 \varphi-1 / 2}}-1
$$

which represents the percentage change of (4.2) with respect to the optimal value of (4.2) when $G_{b}$ is positive $(K=n)$, and where $v=G_{b} / \sigma^{2}$. This previous expression depends on $v$,

![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)

Figure 3: The relative loss (RL) of bias and second-order MSE with respect to the optimal choice for nuisance parameter estimators with slower $(\varphi=1 / 4)$ and faster $(\varphi=1 / 2)$ convergence rates, where $n=1,000$.
which may be difficult to know in empirical applications. When $v$ is positive, the expression in (4.4) is an increasing function of $v$ for any $K \leq n$. In particular, it can be bounded by the following expression,

$$
\frac{\left(1+\frac{1}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi-1 / 2}}{\left(1+\frac{1}{n-1}\right)^{2 \varphi-1 / 2}}-1
$$

which only depends on $K, n$, and $\zeta=2 \varphi-1 / 2$. Panel (b) in Figure 3 presents the previous expression in percentages as a function of $K$. It follows from (4.4) and the figure that when $K=10$, the relative loss of the second-order asymptotic MSE is between $0.2 \%$ and $5 \%$; therefore, it is at most $5 \%$. Figure 3 considered $n=1,000$; nevertheless, the results do not change whenever $n \geq 1,000$.

Remark 4.2. The third lesson uses the second-order asymptotic MSE as an optimality criterion to evaluate the implementation of DML2. In particular, it was used to guide how to select the number of folds $K$ by minimizing the second-order MSE of $\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}$. This criterion can be interpreted as an accuracy criterion since SO-MSE $\left[\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}\right]$ can be interpreted as an approximation to the MSE of $\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}$ based on the following informal derivations

$$
E\left[\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\theta_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \stackrel{(1)}{\approx} n^{-1} E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{2}\right] \stackrel{(2)}{\approx} \mathrm{SO}-\mathrm{MSE}\left[\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}\right]
$$

where (1) is motivated by the stochastic expansion in Theorem 3.3 and (2) by the calculations based on the Corollary 3.1. A similar criterion has been used by Linton (1995) to select an optimal bandwidth and by Donald and Newey (2001) to select the optimal number of instruments, while Newey and Smith (2004) used a similar idea to compare estimators sharing

the same asymptotic distribution.

Remark 4.3. Simulation evidence presented in Section 5 is consistent with $G_{b}>0$ in (4.2). However, testing whether $G_{b}$ is positive is left for future research.

Remark 4.4. The second-order MSE described in Remark 4.2 defines an optimality criterion that can be used to compare different decisions regarding the implementation of DML. In this paper, I used this criterion to select $K$. However, it can also be applied to select bandwidths or estimators for the nuisance function in applications. These alternative uses, however, are beyond the scope of this paper and are left for future research.

# 5 Monte-Carlo Simulations 

This section examines the asymptotic results presented in Section 3 in finite samples. Specifically, I present the bias and mean square error (MSE) of estimators based on DML1 and DML2 building on the Monte Carlo simulation designs for ATT-DID from Sant'Anna and Zhao (2020) and for LATE from Hong and Nekipelov (2010). Additionally, I present the coverage probability of confidence intervals constructed as in Chernozhukov et al. (2018). For the sake of readability, these confidence intervals are defined next

$$
C I_{j}(1-\alpha)=\left[\hat{\theta}_{n, j}-z_{1-\alpha / 2} \frac{\hat{\sigma}_{n, j}}{\sqrt{n}}, \hat{\theta}_{n, j}+z_{1-\alpha / 2} \frac{\hat{\sigma}_{n, j}}{\sqrt{n}}\right]
$$

where $z_{1-\alpha}$ is the $1-\alpha$ quantile of the standard normal distribution,

$$
\hat{\sigma}_{n, j}^{2}=\frac{n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m\left(W_{i}, \hat{\theta}_{n, j}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right)^{2}}{\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right)\right)^{2}}
$$

$\hat{\theta}_{n, j}$ is as in (2.6) and (2.7) for DML1 and DML2, respectively, and $\hat{\eta}_{i}$ is as in (2.5).

### 5.1 Difference-in-Difference

This section is based on Example 2.2. I built on the simulation design presented in Sant'Anna and Zhao (2020). The observed outcome in the pre-treatment period and the potential outcomes in the post-period treatment are defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{0, i} & =f_{\text {reg }}\left(X_{i}\right)+v\left(X_{i}, A_{i}\right)+\varepsilon_{0, i} \\
Y_{1, i}(a) & =2 f_{\text {reg }}\left(X_{i}\right)+v\left(X_{i}, A_{i}\right)+\varepsilon_{1, i}(a), \quad a=0,1
\end{aligned}
$$

where $f_{\text {reg }}(X)=210+6.85 X_{1}+3.425\left(X_{2}+X_{3}+X_{4}\right)$ and $v\left(X_{i}, A_{i}\right)=A_{i} f_{\text {reg }}(X)+\varepsilon_{v, i}$, and $\left(\varepsilon_{0, i}, \varepsilon_{1, i}(0), \varepsilon_{1, i}(1), \varepsilon_{v, i}\right)$ is distributed as $N\left(0, I_{4}\right), I_{4}$ is the $4 \times 4$ identity matrix. The treatment assignment is defined by $A_{i} \sim \operatorname{Bernoulli}\left(p\left(X_{i}\right)\right)$, where

$$

f_{p s}(X) & =0.25\left(-X_{1}+0.5 X_{2}-0.25 X_{3}-0.1 X_{4}\right)

Finally, the vector of covariates is $X_{i}=\left(X_{1, i}, X_{2, i}, X_{3, i}, X_{4, i}\right) \in[0,1]^{4}$ and all its coordinates are independent uniform random variables (e.g., $X_{1, i} \sim$ Uniform $[0,1]$ ).

The estimators for the ATT-DID are defined as in (2.6) and (2.7) using $\psi^{a}$ and $\psi^{b}$ presented in Example 2.2. To estimate the $j$ th component of the vector of nuisance functions $\eta_{0}$, I use the Nadaraya-Watson estimator with a 6th-order Gaussian kernel and common bandwidth $h_{j}=c n_{0}^{-1 / 16}$ for all coordinates, where $n_{0}=(K-1) / K n .^{4}$

I consider a sample size $n=3,000$, different values for the choice of the number of folds $K \in\{2,5,10, \ldots, 30\}$, and perform 5,000 simulations. I additionally consider different values for the constant $c \in\{0.37,0.62,0.86,1.11\}$ in the bandwidth.

# 5.2 Local Average Treatment Effects 

This section is based on Example 2.3. I built on the simulation design presented in Hong and Nekipelov (2010). The potential treatment decisions are defined as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& D_{i}(1)=I\left\{X_{i}+0.5 \geq V_{i}\right\} \\
& D_{i}(0)=I\left\{X_{i}-0.5 \geq V_{i}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $X_{i} \sim \operatorname{Uniform}[0,1]$ and $V_{i} \sim N(0,1)$ are independent random variables. The potential outcomes are defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y_{i}(1)=\xi_{1, i}+\xi_{3, i} I\left\{D_{i}(1)=1, D_{i}(0)=1\right\}+\xi_{4, i} I\left\{D_{i}(1)=0, D_{i}(0)=0\right\} \\
& Y_{i}(0)=\xi_{2, i}+\xi_{3, i} I\left\{D_{i}(1)=1, D_{i}(0)=1\right\}+\xi_{4, i} I\left\{D_{i}(1)=0, D_{i}(0)=0\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\xi_{1, i} \sim \operatorname{Poisson}\left(\exp \left(X_{i} / 2\right)\right), \xi_{2, i} \sim \operatorname{Poisson}\left(\exp \left(X_{i} / 2\right)\right), \xi_{3, i} \sim \operatorname{Poisson}(2)$, and $\xi_{1, i} \sim$ Poisson(1), and all these random variables are independent conditional on $X_{i}$. The treatment assignment is defined by $Z_{i} \sim \operatorname{Bernoulli}\left(\Phi\left(X_{i}-0.5\right)\right)$. As in Example 2.3, the observed treatment decision and the observed outcome are defined by $D_{i}=Z_{i} D_{i}(1)+\left(1-Z_{i}\right) D_{i}(0)$ and by $Y_{i}=D_{i} Y_{i}(1)+\left(1-D_{i}\right) Y_{i}(0)$, respectively.

The estimators for the LATE are defined as in (2.6) and (2.7) using $\psi^{a}$ and $\psi^{b}$ presented in Example 2.3. To estimate the $j$ th component of the vector of nuisance functions $\eta_{0}$, I use the Nadaraya-Watson estimator with a 2th-order Gaussian kernel and common bandwidth $h_{j}=c n_{0}^{-1 / 5}$, where $n_{0}=(K-1) / K n$.

I consider a sample size $n=3,000$, different values for the choice of the number of folds $K \in\{2,5,10, \ldots, 30\}$, and perform 5,000 simulations. I additionally consider different values for the constant $c \in\{0.32,0.53,0.74,0.95\}$ in the bandwidth.

Figures 6 and 7 present the results of the simulations in terms of bias, MSE, and coverage probability. Figure 6 compares the performance between the DML1 and DML2 estimators across different values of $K$, with $c=0.53$. Panel (a) presents the absolute value of the scaled bias. It shows that the bias of DML1 is approximately an increasing linear function of $K$, which is consistent with the intuition presented in Remark 3.6 since the discrepancy measure $\Lambda$ for the LATE in Example 2.3 is different than zero. In contrast, the bias of DML2 decreases as $K$ increases, consistent with Theorem 3.4. Panel (b) presents the scaled MSE. It reveals that the scaled MSE for DML1 is increasing and approximately quadratic on $K$. This finding aligns with the expressions presented in Remark 3.10 for the oracle version of DML1. Additional simulation results presented in Figure 10 in Appendix D show that the DML1 estimator and its oracle version exhibit similar values. In contrast, the scaled

# 6 Concluding Remarks 

This paper studies the properties of debiased machine learning (DML) estimators under a novel asymptotic framework. DML is an estimation method suited to economic models where the parameter of interest depends on unknown nuisance functions that must be estimated. In practice, two versions of DML -introduced by Chernozhukov et al. (2018)—can be used, DML1 and DML2. Both versions randomly divide the data into $K$ equal-sized folds to estimate the nuisance function, but they differ in how these estimates are used to estimate the parameters of interest. In this paper, I consider an asymptotic framework in which $K$ diverges to infinity as $n$ diverges to infinity, accommodating small-sample situations where the practitioner may wish to increase $K$, situations not well approximated by the existing framework in which $K$ is fixed as $n$ diverges.

Under this framework, this paper makes several contributions. First, it shows that DML2 asymptotically dominates DML1 in terms of bias and mean square error. Furthermore, it characterizes the first-order asymptotic difference between DML1 and DML2 using a discrepancy measure, $\Lambda$, which can be computed for several treatment effect parameters. Second, it provides conditions under which all DML2 estimators, regardless of $K$, are asymptotically valid and share the same limiting distribution. To distinguish among them, this paper uses higher-order asymptotic approximations, leading to the final contribution: setting $K=n$ to implement DML2 can be asymptotically optimal in terms of higher-order asymptotic bias and second-order asymptotic MSE within the class of DML2 estimators.

# A Additional Examples and Results
## A. 1 More Examples

Example A. 1 (Weighted Average Treatment Effect). This example is built on the setup of Example 2.1 (ATE) and the parameter considered in Equation (2) of Hirano et al. (2003). The parameter of interest is defined by

$$
\theta_{0}=E[E[(Y(1)-Y(0)) \mid X] g(X)] / E[g(X)]
$$

where $g(\cdot)$ is a known function of covariates $X$, such that $|g(X)|$ is bounded and $E[g(X)]>0$. When $g(X)$ equals the propensity score $E[A \mid X]$, the parameter $\theta_{0}$ equals the average treatment effect on the treated, which implicitly assumes perfect knowledge of the propensity score. Under the selection-on-observables assumptions, the parameter $\theta_{0}$ can be identified by a moment condition, such as (2.1), using a moment function like (2.2), where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi^{b}(W, \eta)=g(X)\left(\eta_{1}-\eta_{2}+A\left(Y-\eta_{1}\right) \eta_{3}-(1-A)\left(Y-\eta_{2}\right) \eta_{4}\right) \\
& \psi^{a}(W, \eta)=g(X)
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\eta \in \mathbf{R}^{4}$, and where the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}(X)$ is exactly the same as in Example 2.1. This moment function appears as the efficient influence function in Hirano et al. (2003) for the weighted average treatment effect. In this example,

$$
\Lambda=E\left[g(X)^{2}\left\{\eta_{0,1}(X)-\eta_{0,2}(X)-\theta_{0}\right\}\right] / E[g(X)]^{2}
$$

which is typically different than zero.
Example A. 2 (Average Treatment Effect on the Treated). This example is built on the setup of Example 2.1 (ATE). It is assumed that there is no knowledge of the propensity score $E[A \mid X]$, and it has to be estimated. The parameter of interest is

$$
\theta_{0}=E[Y(1)-Y(0) \mid A=1]
$$

which is the treatment effect for the treated group, also known as ATT. Under selection-onobservable assumptions, the parameter $\theta_{0}$ can be identified by a moment condition, such as (2.1), using a moment function like (2.2), where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi^{b}(W, \eta)=A\left(Y-\eta_{1}\right)+(1-A)\left(1-\eta_{2}\right)\left(Y-\eta_{1}\right) \\
& \psi^{a}(W, \eta)=A
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\eta \in \mathbf{R}^{2}$, and where the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}(X)$ has two components:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \eta_{0,1}(X)=E[Y \mid X, A=0] \\
& \eta_{0,2}(X)=(E[1-A \mid X])^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

When there is no knowledge of the propensity score, this moment function appears as the efficient influence function for the ATT in Hahn (1998) and Hirano et al. (2003). In this example, $\Lambda=0$.

Example A. 3 (Partial Linear Model). This example presents the model studied in Robinson (1988) and Linton (1995). Consider the following model:

$$
Y=D \theta_{0}+g(X)+U
$$

where $E[U \mid D, X]=0$. Here $W=(Y, D, X)$. The parameter of interest is $\theta_{0}$. In this example, $\theta_{0}$ can be identified by (2.1) and (2.2), where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi^{a}(W, \eta)=\left(D-\eta_{2}\right)^{2} \\
& \psi^{b}(W, \eta)=\left(Y-\eta_{1}\right)\left(D-\eta_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\eta \in \mathbf{R}^{2}$, and where the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}(X)$ has two components:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \eta_{0,1}(X)=E[Y \mid X] \\
& \eta_{0,2}(X)=E[D \mid X]
\end{aligned}
$$

In this example, $\Lambda=0$.
Example A. 4 (Partial Linear IV Model). This example presents the extended PLM. Consider the following model:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& Y=D \theta_{0}+g(X)+U \\
& Z=m(X)+V
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E[U \mid D, Z]=0$ and $E[V \mid X]=0$. Here $W=(Y, D, X, Z)$. The parameter of interest is $\theta_{0}$. In this example, $\theta_{0}$ can be identified by (2.1) and (2.2), where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \psi^{a}(W, \eta)=\left(D-\eta_{2}\right)\left(Z-\eta_{3}\right) \\
& \psi^{b}(W, \eta)=\left(Y-\eta_{1}\right)\left(Z-\eta_{3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\eta \in \mathbf{R}^{3}$, and where the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}(X)$ has three components:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \eta_{0,1}(X)=E[Y \mid X] \\
& \eta_{0,2}(X)=E[D \mid X]) \\
& \eta_{0,3}(X)=E[Z \mid X])
\end{aligned}
$$

In this example, $\Lambda$ is typically different than zero.

# A. 2 Additional Results for DML2 estimators 

Let $\delta_{n_{0}}$ and $b_{n_{0}}$ be the functions defined in Assumption 3.2. For $j \neq i$, define

$$
\tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i}\right)=E\left[b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{j}, X_{i}\right) \mid X_{i}\right]
$$

Recall $\eta_{i}=\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right)$ and consider the following notation:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& J_{0}=E\left[\psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right)\right] \\
& D_{i}=\left.J_{0}^{-1}\left(\partial_{\eta} m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \eta\right)\right|_{\eta=\eta_{i}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the previous notation, consider the stochastic approximation terms:

- $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{t}$ is the asymptotic second-order linear term and

$$
\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{t}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \Delta_{i}^{\top} D_{i}
$$

where $\Delta_{i}$ and $D_{i}$ are as in (3.13) and (A-2), respectively.

- $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ is the asymptotic high-order DML term of the DML2 estimator and

$$
\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}=-n^{-1 / 2}\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)
$$

- $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{d m l 1}$ is the asymptotic high-order DML term of the DML1 estimator

$$
\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{d m l 1}=-n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)
$$

where $m_{i}=m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \eta_{i}\right), \psi_{i}^{a}=\psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right)$, and $n_{k}=n / K$.

The next assumption complements Assumption 3.3 to derive valid stochastic expansions for DML2 estimators when $\varphi_{1}<\varphi_{2}$.

# Assumption A.1. 

(a) The following limits exist and are finite,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& G_{\delta}^{l}=\lim _{n_{0} \rightarrow \infty} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)^{\top} D_{i}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{i}, X_{j}\right)^{\top} D_{j}+\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)^{\top} D_{i}\right)\right] \\
& G_{b}^{l}=\lim _{n_{0} \rightarrow \infty} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right) \tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i}\right)^{\top} D_{i}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

(b) $G_{\delta}^{l}>0$

The next theorem is an extension of Theorem 3.3. It considers valid stochastic expansions for $\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in(1 / 4,1 / 2) \times(1 / 4,1)$. It uses the following notation:

- $\mathcal{R}_{1}=\left\{\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in(1 / 4,1 / 2) \times(1 / 4,1): \varphi_{1}<1 / 3\right.$ or $\left.\varphi_{2}<1 / 2\right\}$.
- $\mathcal{R}_{2}=\left\{\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in(1 / 4,1 / 2) \times(1 / 4,1): \varphi_{1} \geq 1 / 3, \varphi_{2} \geq 1 / 2,\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \notin \mathcal{R}_{3}\right\}$.
- $\mathcal{R}_{3}=\left\{\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in(1 / 4,1 / 2) \times(1 / 4,1): \varphi_{1} \geq 3 / 8, \varphi_{2} \geq 1 / 2, \varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2} \geq 1\right\}$.

Theorem A.1. Suppose Assumptions 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 hold. In addition, assume that $K$ is such that $K \leq n$ and $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. If $\varphi_{1} \in(1 / 4,1 / 2)$, and $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$, then

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\theta_{0}\right)=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}+R_{n, K}
$$

where $\zeta=\min \left\{4 \varphi_{1}-1, \varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2\right\}, \hat{\theta}_{n, 2}$ is as in (2.7), and

- Case 1: $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$ if $\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{R}_{1}$, where $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}$ is defined in (3.11) and $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*} \xrightarrow{d} N\left(0, \sigma^{2}\right)$ with $\sigma^{2}$ defined in (2.11), $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$ is defined in (3.12) and satisfies (i) $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \inf _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]>0$ and (ii) $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} E\left[\left(n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right)^{2}\right]<\infty$.

For the next two cases, suppose in addition that Assumption A. 1 holds.

- Case 2: $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$ if $\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{R}_{2}$, where $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}$ and $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$ are defined as in Case 1, $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$ is defined in (A-3) and satisfies (i) $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \inf _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[n^{\varphi_{1}} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]>0$ and (ii) $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} E\left[\left(n^{\varphi_{1}} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right)^{2}\right]<\infty$.
- Case 3: $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ if $\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{R}_{3}$, where $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$ are defined as in Case 1 and 2, $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ is defined in (A-4) and $n^{1 / 2} \mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ has a nondegenerate limit distribution.

with

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(n^{\zeta}\left|R_{n, K}\right|>\epsilon\right)=0
$$

for any given $\epsilon>0$.
Remark A.1. When $K$ is fixed as $n \rightarrow \infty$ and $\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{R}_{3}$, the following stochastic expansion can be derived for DML1 estimators,

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}-\theta_{0}\right)=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 1}+o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
$$

where $\zeta=\min \left\{4 \varphi_{1}-1, \varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2\right\}$ and $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 1}$ is defined in (A-5). Furthermore, the stochastic expansion presented for DML2 in Theorem A. 1 for case $3\left(\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{R}_{3}\right)$ is also valid when $K$ is fixed as $n \rightarrow \infty$. For convenience, it is presented below

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\theta_{0}\right)=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}+o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
$$

These expressions show that, for the values of $\left(\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{R}_{3}$, both stochastic expansions are only different in $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 1}$ and $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$, which capture the effects of implementing DML.

Theorem A.2. Suppose Assumptions 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 hold. In addition, assume that $K$ is such that $K \leq n$ and $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. If $\varphi_{1} \in(1 / 4,1 / 2), \varphi_{2}<1$, and $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$, then

$$
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}\right]=F_{K} n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}+\nu_{n, K}
$$

where

$$
F_{K}= \begin{cases}\left(F_{\delta}+F_{b}\right)\left(1+\frac{1}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi_{1}} & \text { if } \varphi_{1}=\varphi_{2} \\ F_{\delta}\left(1+\frac{1}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi_{1}} & \text { if } \varphi_{1}<\varphi_{2}\end{cases}
$$

and

$$
\sup _{K \leq n}\left|\nu_{n, K}\right|=o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)
$$

with $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}$ defined as in Theorem A.1, and $F_{\delta}$ and $F_{b}$ defined as in (3.3) and (3.4), respectively.
Theorem A.3. Suppose Assumptions 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 hold. In addition, assume that $K$ is such that $K \leq n$ and $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. If $\varphi_{1} \in(1 / 4,1 / 2), \varphi_{2}<1$, and $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$, then

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}\right]=\sigma^{2}+\Omega_{K} / n^{\zeta}+r_{n, K}
$$

where

$$
\Omega_{K}= \begin{cases}G_{b}\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{\zeta} & \text { if } 3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2>\varphi_{2} \\ \left(G_{\delta} \frac{K^{2}-3 K+3}{(K-1)^{2}}+G_{b}\right)\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{\zeta} & \text { if } 3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2=\varphi_{2} \\ G_{\delta}\left(\frac{\left(K^{2}-K+3\right)}{(K-1)^{2}}\right)\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{\zeta} & \text { if } 3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2<\varphi_{2}\end{cases}
$$

and

$$
\sup _{K \leq n}\left|r_{n, K}\right|=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
$$

with $\zeta=\min \left\{4 \varphi_{1}-1, \varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2\right\}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}$ defined as in Theorem A.1, and $\sigma^{2}, G_{\delta}$ and $G_{b}$ defined as in (2.11), (3.2), and (3.5), respectively.

Corollary A.1. Suppose Assumptions 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 hold. In addition, assume that $K$ is such that $K \leq n$ and $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. If $\varphi_{1} \in(1 / 4,1 / 2), \varphi_{2}<1$, and $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$, then

$$
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{2}\right]=\sigma^{2}+\tilde{\Omega}_{K} / n^{\zeta}+\tilde{r}_{n, K}
$$

where

$$
\tilde{\Omega}_{K}= \begin{cases}G_{b}\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{\zeta} & \text { if } 3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2>\varphi_{2} \\ \left(G_{\delta} \frac{K^{2}-3 K+3}{(K-1)^{2}}+G_{b}+F_{\delta}^{2}\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)\right)\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{\zeta} & \text { if } 3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2=\varphi_{2} \\ \left(G_{\delta} \frac{\left(K^{2}-3 K+3\right)}{(K-1)^{2}}+F_{\delta}^{2}\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)\right)\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{\zeta} & \text { if } 3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2<\varphi_{2}\end{cases}
$$

$$
\sup _{K \leq n}\left|\tilde{r}_{n, K}\right|=O\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)
$$

with $\zeta=\min \left\{4 \varphi_{1}-1, \varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2\right\}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}$ defined as in Theorem A.1, and $\sigma^{2}, F_{\delta}, G_{\delta}$, and $G_{b}$ defined as in (2.11), (3.3), (3.5), and (3.2), respectively.

# Tuning of Nuisance Parameters 

The second-order asymptotic MSE can be defined by

$$
\mathrm{SO}-\mathrm{MSE}\left[\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}\right]=\sigma^{2} / n+\tilde{\Omega}_{K} / n^{\zeta+1}
$$

where $\sigma^{2}$ is the variance of the asymptotic distribution of the estimator $\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}$ defined in (2.11), $\tilde{\Omega}_{K}$ is the higher-order asymptotic MSE defined in (A-11), $\zeta=\min \left\{4 \varphi_{1}-1, \varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2\right\}$, $\varphi_{1}$ is such that $n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}$ is the convergence rate of the variance of the nuisance parameter estimator, and $\varphi_{2}$ is such that $n^{-\varphi_{2}}$ is the convergence rate of the bias of the nuisance parameter estimator.

The explicit formulas for the second-order asymptotic MSE show that tuning the nuisance parameter estimators optimally may still be suboptimal for estimating $\theta_{0}$. Available recommendations for tuning the nuisance parameter estimators often rely on minimizing an out-of-sample prediction error, which can be interpreted as recommendations that minimize the asymptotic integrated mean square error and guarantee optimal convergence rates for the nuisance parameter estimators. However, it is unclear if these recommendations are optimal for estimating the parameter of interest. In particular, the optimal tuning of the estimators for the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}$ alone may be suboptimal for the parameter of interest $\theta_{0}$. To illustrate this point, I consider Example 2.1 (ATE) using the Nadaraya-Watson (N-W) estimators for the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}$. More concretely, I first obtain the values of $\varphi_{1}$ and $\varphi_{2}$ associated with the N-W estimators, and I then use them in (A-12) to derive the optimal convergence rate of the bandwidth based on the criterion.

For the sake of exposition I consider the case where the covariate $X$ is univariate (e.g., $d_{x}=1$ ), and the N-W uses a second-order kernel; see Appendix A. 3 for additional details for the general case. Let $h_{j}=c_{j} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{0}}$ be the bandwidth used for estimating the component $\eta_{0, j}$ of $\eta_{0}$, where $c_{j}$ is a given positive constant and $n_{0}=((K-1) / K) n$ is the sample size used for the estimation. In this case, it can be shown that

$$
\varphi_{1}=\left(1-\varphi_{0}\right) / 2 \quad \text { and } \quad \varphi_{2}=2 \varphi_{0}
$$

where $\varphi_{0} \in[1 / 5,1 / 2)$ to guarantee that $\varphi_{1} \in(1 / 4,1 / 2)$ and $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$. Using this notation, it follows that

$$
\zeta=\min \left\{1-2 \varphi_{0}, 3 \varphi_{0} / 2\right\}
$$

which is lower or equal than $3 / 7$.
In this example, the optimal convergence rate of the second term in (A-12) is $O\left(n^{-10 / 7}\right)$ since $\zeta \leq 3 / 7$. This convergence rate is achieved when the bandwidth has a convergence rate $n^{-2 / 7}$ (i.e., $\varphi_{0}=2 / 7$ ). Importantly, this convergence rate is different than the optimal convergence rate of the bandwidth for the N-W estimators, which is $n^{-1 / 5}$. Therefore, the optimal tuning of the estimators for the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}$ alone is suboptimal for the parameter of interest in this case.

Remark A.2. When $d_{x}=1$ and the N-W estimator uses a second order kernel, then (A-13) also holds for Examples 2 and 3, and the other examples in Appendix A.1. Therefore, the conclusions derived here also apply to these examples. Appendix A. 3 presents additional details and further discussion on the derivation of a general version of (A-13) when covariates $X$ have dimension $d_{x}$ and the N-W estimator uses a kernel of order $s>d_{x} / 2$.

# A. 3 Results for Nadaraya-Watson Estimators 

This section presents explicit expressions for $\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}, \delta_{n}$, and $b_{n}$ when the nuisance parameter estimator $\hat{\eta}$ is the Nadaraya-Watson (N-W) estimator. Specifically, it considers the N-W estimators with a common bandwidth for all coordinates, where the kernel function is the product of the same univariate kernels:

$$
K_{h}(x)=h^{-d_{x}} \prod_{\ell=1}^{d_{x}} K\left(x_{\ell} / h\right), \quad x \in \mathbf{R}^{d_{x}}
$$

where $h=C_{h} n^{-\varphi_{0}}$ is the bandwidth and $K(\cdot)$ is a bounded symmetric kernel of order $s$.
Let $\eta_{0, j}(x)$ be the $j$ th component of the nuisance parameter $\eta_{0}$. Let $f(x)$ be the density function of the covariates $X$ at $x$. In what follows, I consider three possible types for this component:
Type 1: Simple conditional expectation, $\eta_{0, j}(x)=E[Y \mid X=x]$. In this case,

$$
\hat{\eta}_{0, j}(x)=\frac{\sum_{\ell=1}^{n} Y_{\ell} K_{h}\left(x-X_{\ell}\right)}{\sum_{\ell=1}^{n} K_{h}\left(x-X_{\ell}\right)}
$$

By matching the convergence rate of the variance of this estimator $\left(\left(n h^{d}\right)^{-1}\right)$ with $n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}$, it follows that:

$$
\varphi_{1}=\left(1-d_{x} \varphi_{0}\right) / 2
$$

and by matching the convergence rate of the bias of this estimator $\left(h^{s}\right)$ with $n^{-\varphi_{2}}$, it follows that:

$$
\varphi_{2}=s \varphi_{0}
$$

Finally, the $j$ th component of the functions $\delta_{n}$ and $b_{n}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \delta_{n, j}(W, x)=C_{h}^{-d_{x} / 2} h^{d_{x} / 2}\left(Y-\eta_{0, j}(X)\right) K_{h}(x-X) / f(x) \\
& b_{n, j}(W, x)=h^{-s}\left(\eta_{0, j}(X)-\eta_{0, j}(x)\right) K_{h}(x-X) / f(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $X$ is a sub-vector of $W=(Y, X)$. Note that the dependence of these functions on $n$ is due to the definition of bandwidth $h=C_{h} n^{-\varphi_{0}}$.

Type 2: Conditional expectation of a sub-group, $\eta_{0, j}(x)=E[Y \mid A=1, X=x]$. In this case,

$$
\hat{\eta}_{0, j}(x)=\frac{\sum_{\ell=1}^{n} Y_{\ell} A_{\ell} K_{h}\left(x-X_{\ell}\right)}{\sum_{\ell=1}^{n} A_{\ell} K_{h}\left(x-X_{\ell}\right)}
$$

The same arguments presented for type 1 imply

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \varphi_{1}=\left(1-d_{x} \varphi_{0}\right) / 2 \\
& \varphi_{2}=s \varphi_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, the $j$ th component of the functions $\delta_{n}$ and $b_{n}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \delta_{n, j}(W, x)=C_{h}^{-d_{x} / 2} h^{d_{x} / 2}\left\{\left(Y A-g_{1}(X)\right)-\eta_{0, j}(x)\left(A-g_{2}(X)\right)\right\} K_{h}(x-X) / f(x) \\
& b_{n, j}(W, x)=h^{-s}\left\{\left(g_{1}(X)-g_{1}(x)\right)-\eta_{0, j}(x)\left(g_{2}(X)-g_{2}(x)\right)\right\} K_{h}(x-X) / f(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $g_{1}(x)=E[Y A \mid X=x]$ and $g_{2}(x)=E[A \mid X=x], X$ is a sub-vector of $W=(Y, A, X)$.

Type 3: Inverse of propensity score, $\eta_{0, j}(x)=(E[A \mid X=x])^{-1}$. In this case,

$$
\hat{\eta}_{0, j}(x)=\frac{\sum_{\ell=1}^{n} K_{h}\left(x-X_{\ell}\right)}{\sum_{\ell=1}^{n} A_{\ell} K_{h}\left(x-X_{\ell}\right)}
$$

Under standard assumptions, it can be shown that $\hat{\eta}_{0, j}$ has the same convergence rates for the variance and bias. Therefore, the arguments presented for type 1 also apply and imply,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \varphi_{1}=\left(1-d_{x} \varphi_{0}\right) / 2 \\
& \varphi_{2}=s \varphi_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, the $j$ th component of the functions $\delta_{n}$ and $b_{n}$ are given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \delta_{n, j}(W, x)=-C_{h}^{-d_{x} / 2} h^{d_{x} / 2}\left(\eta_{0, j}(x)\right)^{2}\left(A-g_{2}(X)\right) K_{h}(x-X) / f(x) \\
& b_{n, j}(W, x)=-h^{-s}\left(\eta_{0, j}(x)\right)^{2}\left(g_{2}(X)-g_{2}(x)\right) K_{h}(x-X) / f(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $g_{2}(x)=E[A \mid X=x]$ and $X$ is sub-vector of $W=(A, X)$.
Remark A.3. Any component of the nuisance parameters considered in Examples 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, A.1, A.2, A.3, and A. 4 is of Type 1, 2, or 3, with minor modification (e.g., $\eta_{0,4}=$ $E[1-A \mid X]$ in Example 2.1 is of type 3$)$.

# B Proofs of Main Results
## B. 1 Proof of Theorems 3.1 and 3.2

The proof of these theorems relies on the following decomposition,

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, j}-\theta_{0}\right)=n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, j}-\hat{\theta}_{n, j}^{*}\right)+n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, j}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)
$$

and three intermediate results. The first two results are Theorems C.1 and C. 2 in Appendix C that imply $n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, j}-\hat{\theta}_{n, j}^{*}\right)=o_{p}(1)$ for $j=1,2$, respectively. These intermediate results rely on part (c) and (d) of Assumption 3.2 to accommodate the challenging situation that arises in the proof due to $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. The third result is Proposition C. 1 in Appendix C that calculates the asymptotic distribution of $n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, j}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)$ for $j=1,2$. These three results and (B-1) complete the proof of the theorem.

## B. 2 Proof of Theorem 3.3

This follows from Theorem A. 1 when $\varphi_{1}=\varphi_{2}$.

## B. 3 Proof of Theorem 3.4

This follows from Theorem A. 2 when $\varphi_{1}=\varphi_{2}$.

## B. 4 Proof of Theorem 3.5

This follows from Theorem A. 3 when $\varphi_{1}=\varphi_{2}$.

## B. 5 Proof of Theorem A. 1

The proof of (A-8) in this theorem relies on the following decomposition,

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\theta_{0}\right)=n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}\right)+n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)
$$

and two intermediate results. The first result is Theorem C. 2 in Appendix C that implies

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}\right)=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\hat{R}_{n, K}
$$

where $n^{\zeta} \hat{R}_{n, K}$ converges to zero in probability uniformly on $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ (equivalently, $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(n^{\zeta}\left|\hat{R}_{n, K}\right|>\epsilon\right)=0$ for any given $\epsilon>0$ ). For case 1 , it follows that $n^{\zeta} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$

converges to zero in probability uniformly on $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. Proposition C. 4 implies (i) $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \inf _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]>0$ and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} E\left[\left(n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right)^{2}\right]<\infty$. For case 2 and 3, under Assumption A.1, Proposition C. 3 implies that (i) $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \inf _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[n^{\varphi_{1}} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]>$ 0 and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} E\left[\left(n^{\varphi_{1}} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right)^{2}\right]<\infty$.

The second result is Proposition C. 2 in Appendix C that implies

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}+O_{p}\left(n^{-1}\right)
$$

This expansion is independent of the number of folds $K$ since the oracle version of DML2 defined in (2.9) does not depend on sample splitting. Furthermore, it is valid for a larger class of parameters identified by (2.1) and can be obtained by standard arguments (e.g., Newey and Smith (2004)). Central Limit Theorem implies $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*} \rightarrow N\left(0, \sigma^{2}\right)$, and Proposition C. 2 implies $n^{1 / 2} \mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ has a non-degenerate limit distribution. Finally, note that in case 1 and $2, n^{\zeta} \mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ converges to zero in probability uniformly on $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ (since $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ does not depend on $K$ ). In case 3 , the remainder error term in (B-3) scaled by $n^{\zeta}$, $n^{\zeta} O_{p}\left(n^{-2}\right)$ converges to zero in probability uniformly on $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$, since equation (B-3) does not depend on $K$.

The proof of (A-8) is completed by adding the previous two results in their respective case.

# B. 6 Proof of Theorem A. 2 

The proof of this theorem considers the definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}$ with more terms (case 3),

$$
\mathcal{T}_{n, K}=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}
$$

and two intermediate results. The first result is Proposition C. 3 that shows $E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]=0$ and Proposition C. 4 that shows

$$
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]=F_{\delta}\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi_{1}} n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}+F_{b}\left(\frac{K}{K-1}\right)^{2 \varphi_{2}} n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{2}}+\nu_{n, K}
$$

The calculation of these terms relies on the structure imposed by part (a) of Assumption 3.2, and the Neyman orthogonality condition implied by part (b) of Assumption 3.1. The second result is Proposition C. 2 in Appendix C that shows $E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}\right]=0$ and $E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right]=\Lambda n^{-1 / 2}$. These two results and the definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}$ complete the proof. For $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}$ in case 1 or 2 , the proof is analogous and uses that $E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right]=\Lambda n^{-1 / 2}$ do not depend on $K$ and is $o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$.

# B. 7 Proof of Theorem A. 3 

In the proof of the next theorem, $x_{n, K}=o(1)$ denotes a real valued sequence $x_{n, K}$ converging to zero uniformly on $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ (equivalently, $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n}\left|x_{n, K}\right|=0$ ).

The proof of this theorem considers the definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}$ with more terms (case 3 ) since the other two cases follow similarly.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}\right] & =\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right] \\
& =\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]+\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right]+2 \operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} \operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]+\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right]+2 \operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}, \mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right)+n^{-\zeta} o(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by the auxiliary results presented in Appendix C. More concretely, Proposition C. 3 implies $\sup _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ and $\sup _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}, \mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right)=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, respectively, part 3 and 4 of Proposition C. 4 imply $\sup _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right)=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and part 1 of Proposition C. 5 implies $\sup _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right)=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$.

To complete the proof, I present below explicit expressions for each of the first three terms in (B-4). Part 4 of Proposition C. 2 is used to compute the second and third terms in (B-4). It shows

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right]+2 \operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}, \mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right)=\Lambda_{1} n^{-1}+O\left(n^{-2}\right)
$$

These calculations are independent of the assumptions on the nuisance parameter estimators and the number of folds since the oracle version of DML2 does not depend on sample splitting.

Part 3 of Proposition C. 2 calculates $\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}\right]$, part 2 of Proposition C. 4 calculates $\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]$, and part 2 of Proposition C. 5 calculates $\operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right)$. All these expressions together compute the first term in (B-4). That is

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]=\sigma^{2}+G_{\delta}\left(\frac{K^{2}-3 K+3}{(K-1)^{2}}\right) n_{0}^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}+G_{b} n_{0}^{1 / 2-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
$$

These calculations all depend on the structure imposed by part (a) of Assumption 3.2.
Finally, there are three possible cases based on $\zeta=\min \left\{4 \varphi_{1}-1, \varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2\right\}$. First, if $3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2>\varphi_{2}$ it follows that $\zeta=\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2<4 \varphi_{1}-1$ and the second term in (B-5) is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. In this case, the third term in (B-5) equals $\Omega_{K} n^{-\zeta}$. Second, if $3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2=\varphi_{2}$, then $\zeta=4 \varphi_{1}-1$. In this case, the sum of the second and third terms in (B-5) equals $\Omega_{K} n^{-\zeta}$. Third, if $3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2<\varphi_{2}$, then $\zeta=4 \varphi_{1}-1<\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2$ and the third term in (B-5) is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. In this case, the second term in (B-5) equals $\Omega_{K} n^{-\zeta}$.

Lemma C.3. Suppose Assumptions 3.1 and 3.2 hold. In addition, assume $K$ is such that $K \leq n, K \rightarrow \infty$ and $K / \sqrt{n} \rightarrow c \in[0,+\infty)$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. If $1 / 4<\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}$ and $\varphi_{1} \leq 1 / 2$, then,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(\max _{k=1, \ldots, K} \mid n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi^{z}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right) \mid>\epsilon\right)=0
$$

and

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(\max _{k=1, \ldots, K} n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}>\epsilon\right)=0
$$

for $z=a, b$, where $\hat{\eta}_{i}$ is as in (2.5) and $\eta_{i}=\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right)$. In particular,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(\max _{k=1, \ldots, K} \mid n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \eta_{i}\right) \mid>\epsilon\right)=0
$$

and

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(\max _{k=1, \ldots, K} \mid n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right)-\psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right) \mid>\epsilon\right)=0
$$

for any given $\epsilon>0$.
Proof. See Section E. 10 in Appendix E.
Lemma C.4. Suppose Assumption 3.2 holds. In addition, assume $K$ is such that $K \leq n$, $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. If $\varphi_{1} \leq 1 / 2$, then

1. $\lim _{\tilde{M} \rightarrow \infty} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(n^{4 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{4}\right)>\tilde{M}\right)=0$,
2. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} n^{2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} E\left[\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}\right]<\infty$,
3. $\lim _{\tilde{M} \rightarrow \infty} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(n^{2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}>\tilde{M}\right)=0$,
4. $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}>\epsilon\right)=0$ when $1 / 4<\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}$, for any given $\epsilon>0$.
where $\eta_{i}=\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right)$ and $\hat{\eta}_{i}$ is as in (2.5).
Proof. See Section E. 11 in Appendix E.

# E Proofs of Auxiliary Results 

Notation: Recall $\hat{\eta}_{i}=\hat{\eta}_{k}\left(X_{i}\right)$ for $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ and $n_{k}=n / K$ is the number of observations on the fold $\mathcal{I}_{k}$. Denote $\psi_{i}^{z}=\psi^{z}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right)$ and $\hat{\psi}_{i}^{z}=\psi^{z}\left(W_{i}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right)$ for $z=a, b ; m_{i}=$ $m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \eta_{i}\right)$, and $\hat{m}_{i}=m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right) ; \partial_{\eta} m_{i}=\partial_{\eta} m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \eta_{i}\right)$ and $\partial_{\eta} \hat{m}_{i}=\partial_{\eta} m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right)$; $\partial_{\eta}^{2} m_{i}=\partial_{\eta}^{2} m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \eta_{i}\right)$ and $\partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{m}_{i}=\partial_{\eta}^{2} m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right)$. Here, $\|\cdot\|$ is the euclidean norm ( $\ell_{2}$ norm), $J_{0}=E\left[\psi_{i}^{a}\right]$, CLT is for Central Limit Theorem, LLN is for Law of Large Numbers, LIE is for Law of Iterated Expectations, C-S is for Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, RHS is for right-hand side.

## E. 1 Proof of Theorem C. 1

Proof. Using the notation of this section, the definitions of the DML1 estimator in (2.6) and the moment function $m$ in (2.2), it follows

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}-\theta_{0}\right)=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \frac{n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{m}_{i}}{n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}}
$$

and similarly for the oracle version defined in (2.8),

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \frac{n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} m_{i}}{n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \psi_{i}^{a}}
$$

Using the previous two expressions,

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}-\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}^{*}\right)=I_{1}+I_{2}
$$

where
$I_{1}=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \frac{n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}\right)}{n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}} I_{2}=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \frac{\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} m_{i}\right)\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \psi_{i}^{a}-\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}\right)}{\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}\right)\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \psi_{i}^{a}\right)}$
In what follows, I will show that both $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$ are $o_{p}(1)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of the theorem.
Claim 1: $I_{1}=o_{p}(1)$. I first rewrite $I_{1}$ using the identity $a(1+b)^{-1}=a-a b(1+b)^{-1}$ with $a=\hat{I}_{1, k}$ and $b=I_{1, k}$, where

$$
\hat{I}_{1, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}\right) / J_{0}
$$

$$
I_{1, k}=n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}
$$

This implies

$$
I_{1}=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \hat{I}_{1, k}-\hat{I}_{1, k} I_{1, k}\left(1+I_{1, k}\right)^{-1}
$$

To show the claim, consider the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{1}\right| & \stackrel{(1)}{\geq}\left|K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \hat{I}_{1, k}\right|+\left(K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|\hat{I}_{1, k}\right|\left|I_{1, k}\right|\right) \times \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq}\left|n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}\right) / J_{0}\right|+\left(K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|\hat{I}_{1, k}\right|\left|I_{1, k}\right|\right) \times O_{p}(1) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} o_{p}(1)+o_{p}(1) \times O_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality used on (E-1) and definition of $I_{1, k}$, (2) holds by definition of $\hat{I}_{1, k}$ and part 2 of Lemma E.1, and (3) hold by part 3 of Lemma C. 2 and (E-2) presented below,

$$
K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|\hat{I}_{1, k}\right|\left|I_{1, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)
$$

I use Taylor expansion and the mean value theorem to write $\hat{I}_{1, k}=\hat{I}_{1,1, k}+\hat{I}_{1,2, k}$ and $I_{1, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left(I_{1,1, k}+I_{1,2, k}+I_{1,3, k}\right)$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{I}_{1,1, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0} \\
& \hat{I}_{1,2, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{m}_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right) / J_{0} \\
& I_{1,1, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0} \\
& I_{1,2, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{a} / J_{0} \\
& I_{1,3, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{m}_{i}=\partial_{\eta}^{2} m\left(W_{i}, \theta_{0}, \tilde{\eta}_{i}\right)$ for some $\tilde{\eta}_{i}$, due to mean value theorem, and similar for $\partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}$. In what follows I prove $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1, j_{1}, k}\right|\left|I_{1, j_{2}, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$ for $j_{1}=1,2$ and $j_{2}=1,2,3$, which is sufficient to prove (E-2).

Claim 1.1: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right|\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. Consider the following

$$
\begin{aligned}
K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right|\left|I_{1,1, k}\right| & \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right| \times n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|I_{1,1, k}\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} o_{p}(1) \times\left(n^{-1 / 2} K\right) \times O_{p}(1) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\hat{I}_{1,1, k}$, (2) holds by Lemma C. 3 and the derivation presented below, and (3) holds since $K=O\left(n^{1 / 2}\right)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1 / 2} K E\left[\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} n^{-1 / 2} K E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} n^{-1 / 2} K O(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since $I_{1,1, k}$ are i.i.d. random variables, (2) holds by Jensen's inequality and definition of $I_{1,1, k}$, and (3) holds since $\left\{\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}: i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random variables and by parts (a) and (c) of Assumption 3.1.
Claim 1.2: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right| \times\left|I_{1,2, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. It follows by

$$
\begin{aligned}
K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right|\left|I_{1,2, k}\right| & \leq \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right| \times \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|I_{1,2, k}\right| \times n^{-1 / 2} K \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} o_{p}(1) \times o_{p}(1) \times O(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by Lemma C. 3 and because $K=O\left(n^{1 / 2}\right)$.
Claim 1.3: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right|\left|I_{1,3, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. It follows by

$$
\begin{aligned}
K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right|\left|I_{1,3, k}\right| & \leq \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right| \times n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta}^{2} \psi_{i}^{a} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)\right| \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right| \times n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(C_{2} p /\left(2\left|J_{0}\right|\right)\right) \times n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2} \\
& =\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|\hat{I}_{1,1, k}\right| \times\left(C_{2} p /\left(2\left|J_{0}\right|\right)\left(K n^{-1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2} n^{1 / 4} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} o_{p}(1) \times O(1) \times n^{1 / 4} \times O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by part (e) of Assumption 3.1 and Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)), (2) holds by Lemmas C. 3 and C. 4 and because $K=O\left(n^{1 / 2}\right)$, and (3) holds since $\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}>1 / 4$.
Claim 1.4: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,2, k}\right|\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|\hat{I}_{1,2, k}\right|\left|I_{1,1, k}\right| \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n^{-1 / 2}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{n}_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq}\left(C_{2} p / 2\right) n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\right|\left|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right|^{2}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} K^{-1 / 2}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq}\left(C_{2} p / 2\right) K^{1 / 2}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K} n^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{4}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=}\left(K n^{-1 / 2}\right)^{1 / 2} n^{1 / 4} \times O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right) \times\left(K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{=} O(1) \times n^{1 / 4} \times O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right) \times O_{p}(1) \\
& \stackrel{(6)}{=} o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by Cauchy-Schwartz and definition of $\hat{I}_{1,2, k}$, (2) holds by part (e) of Assumption 3.1 and Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)), (3) holds by Jensen's inequality, (4) holds by Lemma C.4, (5) holds because $K=O\left(n^{1 / 2}\right), E\left[K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|I_{1,1, k}\right|^{2}\right]=$ $O(1)$ by definition of $I_{1,1, k}$ and due to parts (a) and (c) of Assumption 3.1, and (6) holds since $\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}>1 / 4$.
Claim 1.5: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,2, k}\right|\left|I_{1,2, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. The proof is similar to the proof of Claim 1.3; therefore, it is omitted.

Claim 1.6: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,2, k}\right| \times\left|I_{1,3, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. Consider the derivations,

$$
K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{1,2, k}\right|\left|I_{1,3, k}\right| \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(C_{2} p /\left(2\left|J_{0}\right|\right)\right)^{2} \times\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}\right)^{2}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(2)}{=}\left(C_{2} p /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)^{2} \times n^{1 / 2} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{4} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=}\left(C_{2} p /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)^{2} \times n^{1 / 2} \times O_{p}\left(n^{-4 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by using the definition of $\hat{I}_{1,2, k}$ and $I_{1,3, k}$, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, and Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)), (2) holds by Jensen's inequality, (3) holds by Lemma C.4, and (4) holds since $\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}>1 / 4$.
Claim 2: $I_{2}=o_{p}(1)$. Consider the following representation of $I_{2}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2} & =K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \frac{\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} m_{i}\right)\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \psi_{i}^{a}-\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}\right)}{\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}\right)\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \psi_{i}^{a}\right)} \\
& =K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \frac{n_{k}^{-1 / 2} I_{2, k} \hat{I}_{2, k}}{\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \psi_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{2, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} m_{i} / J_{0} \\
& \hat{I}_{2, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

To show the claim, consider the following derivation

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|I_{2}\right| \stackrel{(1)}{=} \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \times \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \psi_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \times K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|I_{2, k}\right|\left|\hat{I}_{2, k}\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} O_{p}(1) \times O_{p}(1) \times o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality and definition of $I_{2}$, and (2) by Lemma E. 1 and (E-3) presented below,

$$
K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{2, k}\right|\left|I_{2, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)
$$

As in the proof of claim 1, I use Taylor approximation and mean value theorem to write

$\hat{I}_{2, k}=\hat{I}_{2,1, k}+\hat{I}_{2,2, k}$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{I}_{2,1, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{a} / J_{0} \\
& \hat{I}_{2,2, k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right) / J_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, in what follows I prove $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{2, j, k}\right|\left|I_{2, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$ for $j=1,2$, which is sufficient to prove (E-3).
Claim 2.1: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{2,1, k}\right|\left|I_{2, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. The proof is similar to the one in Claim 1.1; therefore, it is omitted.

Claim 2.2: $K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|\hat{I}_{2,2, k}\right|\left|I_{2, k}\right|=o_{p}(1)$. The proof is similar to the one in Claim 1.4; therefore, it is omitted.

# E. 2 Proof of Theorem C. 2 

Proof. Notation: In the proof of this theorem, $x_{n, K}=o_{p}(1)$ denotes a sequence of random variables $x_{n, K}$ converging to zero uniformly on $K \rightarrow \infty$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ (equivalently, $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} P\left(\left|x_{n, K}\right|>\epsilon\right)=0$ for any given $\epsilon>0$ ).

Using the definitions of the DML2 estimator in (2.7) and the moment function $m$ in (2.2), it follows

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\theta_{0}\right)=\frac{n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \hat{m}_{i}}{n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}}
$$

and similarly for the oracle version defined in (2.9),

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=\frac{n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i}}{n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi_{i}^{a}}
$$

Using the previous two expressions, it follows

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}-\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}\right)=I_{1}+I_{2}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=\frac{n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}\right) / J_{0}}{n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a} / J_{0}} \\
& I_{2}=\frac{\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}\right)}{\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show that $I_{1}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ and $I_{2}=o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of the theorem since both $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$ and $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$ are $O_{p}\left(n^{-\varphi_{1}}\right)$ and $O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, respectively, under Assumptions 3.1 and 3.2 and by the proof of Propositions C. 4 and C.5. Furthermore, if Assumption 3.3 holds, part 2 of Proposition C. 5 implies $\operatorname{Var}\left[n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]=G_{\delta}\left(K^{2}-3 K+3\right)(K-1)^{-1-4 \varphi_{1}} K^{4 \varphi_{1}-1}+n^{4 \varphi_{1}-1} r_{n, K}^{n l}$, which implies that $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \inf _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]>0$. Part 1 of Proposition C. 5 implies that $\sup _{K \leq n}\left|n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2} E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]\right|<\infty$; then, $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} E\left[\left(n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right)^{2}\right]<\infty$. Similarly, the proof of Propositions C. 4 guarantees $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{K \leq n} E\left[\left(n^{\varphi_{1}} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right)^{2}\right]<\infty$.
Claim 1: $I_{1}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. I first rewrite the RHS of (E-4) using the identity $a(1+b)^{-1}=a-a b(1+b)^{-1}$, where $a=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}\right) / J_{0}$ and $b=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}$. That is

$$
I_{1}=a-a b(1+b)^{-1}
$$

I then conclude the proof of the claim by using claims 1.1 and 1.2, stated below.
Claim 1.1: $a=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. This result holds by part 4 of Lemma C. 2 since $a=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}\right) / J_{0}$.
Claim 1.2: $a b(1+b)^{-1}=o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Note that part 4 of Lemma C. 2 implies $a=O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$. Note also that part 2 of Lemma C. 2 and CLT imply $b=O_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$, which guarantees that $(1+b)^{-1}=O_{p}(1)$; therefore, $a b(1+b)^{-1}=O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, which is $o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $\varphi_{1}<1 / 2$.
Claim 2: $I_{2}=o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. I first rewrite $I_{2}$ defined in (E-5) as follows,

$$
I_{2}=a b(1+c-b)^{-1}(1+c)^{-1}
$$

where $a=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}, b=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}$, and $c=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}$. CLT implies that $a=O_{p}(1)$ and $c=O_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$. Part 2 of Lemma C. 2 implies $b=O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$. Therefore, $a b=O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, and both $(1+c-b)^{-1}$ and $(1+c)^{-1}$ are $O_{p}(1)$. This implies $I_{2}$ is $O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, which is $o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $\varphi_{1}<1 / 2$.

# E. 3 Proof of Proposition C. 1 

Proof. Part 1: By the definition of the oracle version of the DML1 estimator in (2.8) and the moment function $m$ in (2.2), it follows

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \frac{n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} m_{i}}{n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}} \psi_{i}^{a}}
$$

I first rewrite the RHS of (E-6) using the identity $a_{k}\left(1+b_{k}\right)^{-1}=a_{k}-a_{k} b_{k}+a_{k} b_{k}^{2}\left(1+b_{k}\right)^{-1}$

with $a_{k}=n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} m_{i} / J_{0}$ and $b_{k}=n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}$. That is

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=I_{1}+I_{2}+I_{3}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} a_{k} \\
& I_{2}=-K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} a_{k} b_{k} \\
& I_{3}=K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} a_{k} b_{k}^{2}\left(1+b_{k}\right)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

By CLT, it follows $I_{1}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0} \xrightarrow{d} N\left(0, \sigma^{2}\right)$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$, where $\sigma^{2}$ is as in (2.11). Therefore, if $I_{2}-K / \sqrt{n} \Lambda$ and $I_{3}$ are $o_{p}(1)$, then

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}+K / \sqrt{n} \Lambda+o_{p}(1)
$$

which is sufficient to complete the proof of part 1 since $K / \sqrt{n} \rightarrow c$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$. In what follows, Claim 1 shows $I_{2}-K / \sqrt{n} \Lambda=o_{p}(1)$ and Claim 2 shows $I_{3}$ are $o_{p}(1)$.
Claim 1: $I_{2}-K / \sqrt{n} \Lambda=o_{p}(1)$. First, note that $E\left[-a_{k} b_{k}\right]=K^{1 / 2} / \sqrt{n} \Lambda$ due to the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[a_{k} b_{k}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n_{k}^{-1 / 2} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=}-n^{-1 / 2} K^{1 / 2} \Lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $a_{k}$ and $b_{k}$, (2) holds since $\left\{\left(m_{i}, \psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right): i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors, and (3) holds by the definition of $\Lambda$ in (3.6) and condition (2.1).

Therefore, $E\left[I_{2}\right]=-K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} E\left[a_{k} b_{k}\right]=K / \sqrt{n} \Lambda$, which implies that the claim is equivalent to show that $I_{2}-E\left[I_{2}\right]$ is $o_{p}(1)$, which follows by the following derivations

$$
E\left[\left(I_{2}-E\left[I_{2}\right]\right)^{2}\right] \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[\left(K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(a_{k} b_{k}-E\left[a_{k} b_{k}\right]\right)\right)^{2}\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} E\left[\left(a_{k} b_{k}-E\left[a_{k} b_{k}\right]\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} E\left[\left(a_{k} b_{k}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} n_{k}^{-1} E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{=} n_{k}^{-1} E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{4}\right]^{1 / 2} \times E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)^{4}\right]^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(6)}{=} n_{k}^{-1} \times O(1) \times O(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $I_{2}$; (2) and (3) hold since $\left\{a_{k} b_{k}-E\left[a_{k} b_{K}\right]: 1 \leq k \leq K\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d random variables due to the definition of $a_{k}$ and $b_{k}$; (4) holds by definition of $a_{k}$ and $b_{k}$; (5) holds by Cauchy-Schwartz; and (6) holds since $\left\{\left(m_{i}, \psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right): i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors, parts (a) and (c) of Assumption 3.1, and $n_{k} \rightarrow \infty$. This completes the proof of Claim 1.
Claim 2: $I_{3}=o_{p}(1)$. Consider the following derivation

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{3}\right| & \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} \max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \times K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|a_{k}\right| b_{k}^{2} \\
& =O_{p}(1) \times o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $I_{3}$ and triangular inequality, and (2) holds by Lemma E. 1 and (E-7) presented below,

$$
K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|a_{k}\right| b_{k}^{2}=o_{p}(1)
$$

To prove (E-7), consider the following

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K}\left|a_{k}\right| b_{k}^{2}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} K^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} E\left[\left|a_{k}\right|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} E\left[\left|b_{k}\right|^{4}\right]^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} K^{1 / 2} n_{k}^{-1} E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \times E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)^{4}\right]^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=}\left(K n^{-1 / 2}\right)^{3 / 2} n^{-1 / 4} O(1) \times O(1) \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} o(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by Cauchy-Schwartz, (2) holds since $\left\{\left(a_{k}, b_{k}\right): 1 \leq k \leq K\right\}$ are i.i.d random vectors and the definition of $a_{k}$ and $b_{k}$, (3) holds since $\left\{\left(m_{i}, \psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right): i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors, and parts (a) and (c) of Assumption 3.1, and (4) holds since $K=O\left(n^{1 / 2}\right)$. This completes the proof of Claim 2.
Part 2: By the definition of $\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}$ in (2.9), and the moment function $m$ in (2.2), it follows

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=\frac{n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}}{n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi_{i}^{a} / J_{0}}
$$

Since the denominator converges to 1 in probability by the LLN and the numerator converges to $N\left(0, \sigma^{2}\right)$ in distribution due to the CLT, it follows that $n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)$ converges in distribution to $N\left(0, \sigma^{2}\right)$. This completes the proof of part 2

# E. 4 Proof of Proposition C. 2 

Proof. Part 1: By the definition of the oracle version of DML2 estimator in (2.9), and the moment function $m$ in (2.2), it follows

$$
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right)=\frac{n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i}}{n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi_{i}^{a}}
$$

I rewrite the RHS of (E-8) using the identity $a(1+b)^{-1}=a-a b+a b^{2}(1+b)^{-1}$ with $a=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}$ and $b=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}$. That is

$$
\begin{aligned}
n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 2}^{*}-\theta_{0}\right) & =a-a b+a b^{2}(1+b)^{-1} \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} \mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}+\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}+a b^{2}(1+b)^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by the definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}$ and $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$. It is sufficient to show $a b^{2}(1+b)^{-1}$ is $O_{p}\left(n^{-1}\right)$ to complete the proof, which follows by CLT that implies $a=O_{p}(1)$ and $b=$ $O_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$, and $(1+b)^{-1}=O_{p}(1)$.

Finally, consider the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=}-n^{-1 / 2} E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=}-n^{-1 / 2} \Lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by the definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$, and (2) holds since $\left\{\left(m_{i},\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right): 1 \leq i \leq n\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors and by the definition of $\Lambda$ in (3.6).

Part 2: By definition of $\sigma^{2}$ and since $\left\{\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right): 1 \leq i \leq n\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random variables, it follows that $E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}\right]=0$ and $E\left[\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}\right)^{2}\right]=\sigma^{2}$.
