Part 3: First note that $\operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}, \mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right)=E\left[\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}\right)\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right)\right]$. Now, consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}\right)\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right)\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=}-n^{-1 / 2} E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=}-n^{-1} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\left(\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=}-n^{-1} \Xi_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*}$ and $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$, (2) holds since $\left\{\left(m_{i} / J_{0},\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right): 1 \leq\right.$ $i \leq n\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors, and (3) holds by definition of $\Xi_{1}$ in (C-1).

Similarly, consider the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right]-n^{-1} \Lambda^{2} \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-1}\left(E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right] E\left[\left(\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right]+2 \Lambda^{2}+O\left(n^{-1}\right)\right)-n^{-1} \Lambda^{2} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1}\left(\sigma^{2} \sigma_{a}^{2}+\Lambda^{2}\right)+O\left(n^{-2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l 2}$ and $\Lambda$ in (A-4) and (3.6), respectively, (2) holds since $\left\{\left(m_{i} / J_{0},\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right): 1 \leq i \leq n\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors and by definition of $\Lambda$, and (3) holds by definition of $\sigma^{2}$ and $\sigma_{a}^{2}$ in (2.11) and (C-2), respectively.

# E. 5 Proof of Proposition C. 3 

Proof. For $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$, denote $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{b}+\Delta_{i}^{l}$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{i}^{l}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \delta_{n_{0}, j, i} \\
& \Delta_{i}^{b}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}=\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)$ and $b_{n_{0}, j, i}=b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{j}, X_{i}\right)$, and $\delta_{n_{0}}$ and $b_{n_{0}}$ are functions satisfying Assumption 3.2.
Part 1: Using the previous notation, it holds that $E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right]=0$. To see this,

consider the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0} \mid\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right), X_{i}\right]\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0} \mid X_{i}\right]\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by the law of interactive expectations and because $\Delta_{i}$ is non-stochastic conditional on $\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)$ and $X_{i}$, (2) holds since $\left\{W_{j}: 1 \leq j \leq n\right\}$ are i.i.d. random vectors and $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$, and (3) holds by the Neyman orthogonality condition (part (b) of Assumption 3.1).

Therefore, $E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]=0$ holds due to the definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$ in (A-3) and the previous result,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right] & =n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right] \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

Part 2: By part 1, $\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]=E\left[\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right)^{2}\right]$. Now, consider the following decomposition:

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right)^{2}\right] & =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& =I_{1}+2 I_{2}+I_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

where I use $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{l}+\Delta_{i}^{b}$ in the last equality, with $I_{1}, I_{2}$, and $I_{3}$ defined below,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& I_{2}=n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& I_{3}=n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show $I_{1}=n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} G_{\delta}^{l}+o\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$ with $G_{\delta}^{l}$ defined as in (A-6), $I_{2}=0$, and

$I_{3}=O\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of Part 2.
Claim 1: $I_{1}=n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} G_{\delta}^{l}+o\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1} \\
& =n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& =n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] I\left\{i_{1} \neq i_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] I\left\{i_{1} \neq i_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] I\left\{k_{1} \neq k_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] I\left\{i_{1} \neq i_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] I\left\{k_{1} \neq k_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\left(E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right]+E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\right]\right) \\
& \stackrel{(6)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} G_{\delta}^{l}+o\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds because there are 3 possible situations for $i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}$ and $i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}$ : i) $k_{1} \neq k_{2}$,

ii) $k_{1}=k_{2}$ but $i_{1} \neq i_{2}$, and iii) $i_{1}=i_{2}$, (2) holds by the law of iterative expectations and since

$$
E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) \mid X_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0, \text { when } i_{1} \neq j_{2}
$$

and

$$
E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) \mid X_{i_{2}}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{j_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0, \text { when } i_{2} \neq j_{1}
$$

(3) holds by the law of iterative expectations and since

$$
E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) \mid X_{i_{2}}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{j_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0, \text { when } i_{1} \neq i_{2}
$$

(4) holds since $\left\{\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right): j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are i.i.d. random variables conditional on $W_{i}$ (here I use $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ ), by noting that $\sum_{k_{2}=1}^{K} I_{k_{2} \neq k_{1}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}}(\cdot)=\sum_{i_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}}(\cdot)$, and recalling that $n_{0}$ is the number of observations outside the fold $\mathcal{I}_{k}$, (5) holds because the random variables $\left\{\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right): i_{1} \neq i_{2}\right\}$ are identically distributed, and (6) holds by the definition of $G_{s}^{l}$ in (A-6) and $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$. This completes the proof of claim 1.
Claim 2: $I_{2}=0$. First, consider the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
\stackrel{(1)}{=} & n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
\stackrel{(2)}{=} & 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{i}^{l}$ and $\Delta_{i}^{b}$, and (2) holds by considering 3 possible cases:

- If $j_{1} \neq i_{2}$ and $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$ ( $j_{1}$ different than all other sub-indices), then

$$
E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) \mid W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0
$$

since $E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}} \mid W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2.

- If $j_{1}=i_{2}$, then $i_{2} \neq i_{1}$ (otherwise $j_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ ) and

$$
E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) \mid W_{i_{2}}, X_{i_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0
$$

since $E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}} \mid W_{i_{1}}, X_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2.

- If $j_{1}=j_{2}=j$, then

$$
E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) \mid X_{j}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}\right]=0
$$

since $E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j, i_{1}} \mid X_{j}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}\right]=0$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2.
Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1,2} & =n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which completes the proof of claim 2 .
Claim 3: $I_{3}=O\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$. Algebra shows

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{3}= & n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
= & n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
\leqq & n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, i, j}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\right], \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} n_{0}^{-1}\left(E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}\left(E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, i, j}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& +n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \leqq 2\left(p \tilde{C}_{1} / C_{0}^{2}\right) n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \leqq 2\left(p \tilde{C}_{1} / C_{0}^{2}\right) n_{0}^{-1} n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} \tau_{n_{0}} \\
& \stackrel{(6)}{=} o\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) uses the same argument to calculate $I_{1}$, (2) holds since the random vectors $\left\{\left(b_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}, b_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right): i_{1} \neq i_{2}\right\}$ are identically distributed, (3) holds by Cauchy-

Schwartz inequality, (4) holds by the inequalities (E-9) and (E-10) presented below where $\tilde{C}_{1}$ is a constant depending only on $\left(C_{0}, C_{1}, M\right)$, (5) holds by part (b.4) in Assumption 3.2, and (6) holds since $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$ and $\tau_{n_{0}}=o(1)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \leq\left(p \tilde{C}_{1} / C_{0}^{2}\right) E\left[\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, i, j}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right] \leq\left(p \tilde{C}_{1} / C_{0}^{2}\right) E\left[\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right\|^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

To verify (E-9) consider the following derivation,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{2}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} E\left[\left(\partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}\right)^{\top} \mid X_{j}, X_{i}\right] n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq}\left(1 / C_{0}^{2}\right) E\left[n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} E\left[\left(\partial_{\eta} m_{i}\right)\left(\partial_{\eta} m_{i}\right)^{\top} \mid X_{i}\right] n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} p\left(\tilde{C}_{1} / C_{0}^{2}\right) E\left[\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right\|^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by LIE and since $b_{n_{0}, j, i}$ is non-random conditional on $X_{j}$ and $X_{i}$, (2) holds by part (a) of Assumption 3.1 and independence between $X_{i}$ and $X_{j}$ since $i \neq j$, and (3) holds by definition of euclidean norm and since $\left\|E\left[\left(\partial_{\eta} m_{i}\right)\left(\partial_{\eta} m_{i}\right)^{\top} \mid X_{i}\right]\right\|_{\infty} \leq \tilde{C}_{1}=C_{1}\left(1+M^{1 / 4} / C_{0}\right)^{2}$ due to parts (d) in Assumption 3.1 and $\left|\theta_{0}\right| \leq M^{1 / 4} / C_{0}$ (which holds by definition of $\theta_{0}$ and parts (a) and (c) of Assumption 3.1).

The verification of (E-10) follows the same previous derivations but reverting the role of $i$ and $j$. Lastly, it uses that $E\left[\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, i, j}\right\|^{2}\right]=E\left[\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right\|^{2}\right]$ since $b_{n_{0}, j, i}$ and $b_{n_{0}, i, j}$ have the same distribution for $i \neq j$.

Part 3: By Cauchy-Schwartz, parts 3 of Proposition C.2, and part 2 of this proposition,

$$
\operatorname{Cov}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n}^{d m l}, \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right) \leq\left(\left(G_{\delta}^{l}\right)^{1 / 2}(K /(K-1))^{\varphi_{1}}+o(1)\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\sigma^{2} \sigma_{a}^{2}+\Lambda^{2}+o(1)\right)^{1 / 2} n^{-\varphi_{1}-1 / 2}
$$

which implies the RHS is $O\left(n^{-\varphi_{1}-1 / 2}\right)$, and this is $o\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$ since $\varphi_{1}<1 / 2$.

# E. 6 Proof of Proposition C. 4 

Proof. For $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$, denote $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{b}+\Delta_{i}^{l}$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta_{i}^{l} & =n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \delta_{n_{0}, j, i} \\
\Delta_{i}^{b} & =n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}=\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)$ and $b_{n_{0}, j, i}=b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{j}, X_{i}\right)$, and $\delta_{n_{0}}$ and $b_{n_{0}}$ are functions satisfying Assumption 3.2. Denote $H_{i}=\partial_{q}^{2} m_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)$.
Part 1: Consider the following decomposition using the definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$ in (3.12),

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right] & =n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\Delta_{i}^{\top} H_{i} \Delta_{i}\right] \\
& =I_{1}+2 I_{2}+I_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} H_{i} \Delta_{i}^{l}\right] \\
& I_{2}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} H_{i} \Delta_{i}^{l}\right] \\
& I_{3}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} H_{i} \Delta_{i}^{b}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show $I_{1}=n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} F_{\delta}+o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right), I_{2}=0, I_{3}=n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} F_{b}+o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of Part 1 since $n_{0}=((K-1) / K) n$.

Claim 1: $I_{1}=n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} F_{\delta}+o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} H_{i} \Delta_{i}^{l}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{i}^{l}$, and (2) and (3) hold since $\left\{\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors conditional on $W_{i}$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2 (here I use that $\left.i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1} & =n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)\right] \\
& =n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} F_{\delta}+o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $F_{\delta}$ in (3.3), Assumption A.1, and because $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$. This completes the proof of claim 1.
Claim 2: $I_{2}=0$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{i}^{b}$ and $\Delta_{i}^{l}$, and (2) holds since

$$
E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{q}^{2} m_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right) \mid X_{j_{2}}, X_{j_{1}}, W_{i}\right]=0
$$

due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2 ( $E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i} \mid X_{j_{2}}, W_{i}\right]=0$ ). Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2} & =n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{q}^{2} m_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)\right] \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which completes the proof of claim 2 .
Claim 3: $I_{3}=n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} F_{b}+o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)$. Denote $\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}=E\left[b_{n_{0}, j, i} \mid X_{i}\right]$ for $j \neq i$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)\right] \stackrel{(1)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{i}^{b}$, (2) holds by adding and subtracting $\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}$, and (3) holds since $\left\{b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random vectors conditional on $W_{i}$, which

implies $E\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right) \mid W_{i}\right]=0$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{3} & =n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)\right] \\
& =n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-1} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right]+n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)+n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)+n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} F_{b}+o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{2}}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} F_{b}+o\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by (E-11) presented below and since $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$, (2) holds by definition of $F_{b}$ in (3.4) and Assumption A.1, and (3) since $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$ and $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$.

$$
n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right]=o\left(n^{1-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)
$$

To verify (E-11) consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right]\right| \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}}\left(2 C_{0}\right)^{-1} E\left[\left|\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{0}^{2} m_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right|\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq}\left(2 C_{0}\right)^{-1}\left(p \tilde{C}_{2}\right) E\left[\left|\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}-n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right|^{2}\right]\right. \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} 2\left(2 C_{0}\right)^{-1}\left(p \tilde{C}_{2}\right)\left(E\left[\left|\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right|\right|^{2}\right]+E\left[\left|\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right|\right|^{2}\right]\right) \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{\leq}\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right)\left(n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} \tau_{n_{0}}+n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} M_{1}^{1 / 2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{=} o\left(n^{1-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality and part (a) of Assumption 3.1, (2) holds by definition of euclidean norm and since $\left\|E\left[\partial_{a}^{2} m_{i} \mid X_{i}\right]\right\|_{\infty} \leq \tilde{C}_{2}=C_{2}\left(1+M^{1 / 4} / C_{0}\right)$ due to part (e) of Assumption 3.1 and $\left|\theta_{0}\right| \leq M^{1 / 4} / C_{0}$ (which holds by definition of $\theta_{0}$ and parts (a) and (c) of Assumption 3.1), (3) holds by standard properties of euclidean norm, (4) holds by parts (b.3) and (b.4) of Assumption 3.2 with $\tau_{n_{0}}=o(1)$, and (5) holds since $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$ and $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$.

Part 2: Consider the following decomposition,

$$
\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}-E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]=I_{l, l}+2 I_{l, b}+I_{b, b}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{l, l}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right]\right) \\
& I_{l, b}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right]\right) \\
& I_{b, b}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-E\left[b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Var}\left[\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{u l}\right] & =E\left[\left(I_{l, l}+2 I_{l, b}+I_{b, b}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =E\left[I_{l, l}^{2}\right]+E\left[I_{b, b}^{2}\right]+4 E\left[I_{l, b}^{2}\right]+2 E\left[I_{l, l} I_{b, b}\right]+4 E\left[\left(I_{l, l}+I_{b, b}\right) I_{l, b}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show $E\left[I_{l, l}^{2}\right]=G_{\delta}\left(K^{2}-3 K+3\right)(K-1)^{-2} n_{0}^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right), E\left[I_{b, b}^{2}\right]=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and $E\left[I_{l, b}^{2}\right]=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of Part 2 since $n_{0}=((K-$ 1) $/ K) n$ and by Cauchy-Schwartz it holds $E\left[I_{l, l} I_{b, b}\right]=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and $E\left[\left(I_{l, l}+I_{b, b}\right) I_{l, b}\right]=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$.

Claim 1: $E\left[I_{l, l}^{2}\right]=G_{\delta}\left(K^{2}-3 K+3\right)(K-1)^{-2} n_{0}^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following notation

$$
\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l}=\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right]\right)
$$

Note that $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l}\right]=0$ by construction, and $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$ implies

$$
E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right]=0 \quad \text { and } \quad \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l}=\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}
$$

Therefore, $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l} \mid W_{i}, W_{j_{1}}, X_{j_{2}}\right]=0$ and $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l} \mid W_{i}, W_{j_{2}}, X_{j_{1}}\right]=0$ when $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2. Furthermore,

$$
\left|E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]\right| \leq\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right)^{2} n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} M_{1}
$$

which follows by Cauchy-Schwartz, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, and part (b.2) of Assumption 3.2 , with $\tilde{C}_{2}=C_{2}\left(1+M^{1 / 4} / C_{0}\right)$.

Using the previous notation, $I_{l, l}$ can be written as follows

$$
I_{l, l}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l}
$$

and $E\left[I_{l, l}^{2}\right]$ can be decompose in three terms

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[I_{l, l}^{2}\right] & =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j, j, i}^{l, l}+n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =I_{1}+I_{2}+2 I_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j, j, i}^{l, l}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& I_{2}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, l} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& I_{3}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} \sum_{j_{3} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} \sum_{j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l} I\left\{j_{3} \neq j_{4}\right\}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show that $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right), I_{2}=G_{\delta}\left(K^{2}-3 K+3\right)(K-1)^{-2} n_{0}^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of Claim 1.

Claim 1.1 $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following expansion

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1} & =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right] \\
& =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, i_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{E}=\left\{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in[n]^{4}: i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}, i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}, j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}, k_{1} \in[K], k_{2} \in[K]\right\}$, with $[n]$ denoting $\{1, \ldots, n\}$. Let $\mathcal{E}_{4} \subseteq[n]^{4}$ be the subset of indices with distinct entries. (e.g., $i_{1} \notin\left\{i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right\}, i_{2} \notin\left\{j_{1}, j_{2}\right\}, j_{1} \neq j_{2}$ ). Let $\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3} \subset[n]^{4}$ be the subset of indices with at most three distinct entries.

Now, take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}$. It follows that

$$
E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]=E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\right] E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]=0
$$

due to independence and by definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, l}$.
Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{1}\right| & =\left|n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, i_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \backslash \mathcal{E}_{4}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, i_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}}\left|E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, i_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}}\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right)^{2} n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \times 3^{4} n^{3} \times\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right)^{2} n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} O\left(n^{1-6 \varphi_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality and since $\mathcal{E} \backslash \mathcal{E}_{4} \subset \mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}$, (2) holds by (E-12), (3) holds since the number of elements of $\mathcal{E}_{3}$ is at most $3^{4} n^{3}$ (for each 3 -tuple $(a, b, c) \in[n]^{3}$ consider the functions from the positions $\{1,2,3,4\}$ into the possible values $\{a, b, c\}$, the number of all these functions is $3^{4}$ and there number of 3 -tuple is $n^{3}$ ), and (4) hold since $n / 2 \leq n \leq n$. Therefore, $I_{1}$ is $O\left(n^{1-6 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, which is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $6 \varphi_{1}-1>4 \varphi_{1}-1 \geq \zeta$. This completes the proof of Claim 1.1.

Claim 1.2: $I_{2}=G_{\delta}\left(K^{2}-3 K+3\right)(K-1)^{-2} n_{0}^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following expansion

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2} & =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} \sum_{j_{3}, j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l} I\left\{j_{3} \neq j_{4}\right\}\right)\right] \\
& =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{E}=\left\{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in[n]^{6}: i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}, i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}} ; j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}} ; j_{3}, j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}} ; j_{1} \neq j_{2} ; j_{3} \neq\right.$ $\left.j_{4} ; k_{1}, k_{2} \in[K]\right\}$. Let $\mathcal{E}_{6} \subseteq[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with distinct entries. Let $\mathcal{E}_{5} \subseteq[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with exactly five distinct entries, meaning that two entries are identical while the remaining entries are distinct. Let $\mathcal{E}_{4} \subseteq[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with exactly four distinct entries. Let $\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3} \subset[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with at most three distinct entries. Note that $[n]^{6}=\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3} \cup \mathcal{E}_{4} \cup \mathcal{E}_{5} \cup \mathcal{E}_{6}$.

Now, take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{6}$. It follows that

$$
E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]=0
$$

since $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}$ are independent zero mean random variables.
Now take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$. Without loss of generality, assume that $j_{1}$ is different than all the other indices (otherwise, this statement holds with $j_{2}$ or $j_{3}$ or $j_{4}$ ). Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{4}, i_{2}}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} E\left[E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \mid W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{2}}, W_{j_{3}}, W_{j_{4}}\right]\left(H_{i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{4}, i_{2}}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}$ since $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$ and $j_{3} \neq j_{4}$, (2) holds by LIE, and (3) holds by part (a) of Assumption 3.2. Note that this argument can be used whenever one $j_{s}$ is different than all the other indices, for some $s \in\{1,2,3,4\}$.

Now take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}$. Suppose $\{a, b, c, d\}$ are four different indices, then there are two possible distributions for the 6 -tuples: (i) two pairs, e.g., $(a, a, b, b, c, d)$, or (ii) one triple, e.g., $(a, a, a, b, c, d)$. Notice that for 6 -tuples in (ii), there exists one $j_{s}$ different than all the other indices, for some $s \in\{1,2,3,4\}$. In this case, $E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]$ equals zero due to the argument described above. Therefore, in what follows, I consider only 6 -tuples in (i), specifically, the cases where $j_{s}$ appears in a pair for all $s=1,2,3,4$.

- Case 1: $j_{1}=j_{3}, j_{2}=j_{4}$, and $i_{1} \neq i_{2}$. Then,

$$
E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]=E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right]
$$

To compute the number of indices $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E}$ in this case, recall that $i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}$ and $i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}$, therefore, there are two situations (i) $k_{1}=k_{2}$ or (ii) $k_{1} \neq k_{2}$. For the first situation, $i_{1}$ can take $n$ values, $i_{2}$ can take $n_{k}-1$ values (since it is different than $i_{1}$ but is in the same fold $\mathcal{I}_{k}$ ), and $j_{1}$ and $j_{2}$ can take $n_{0}$ and $n_{0}-1$ values (since they are different but not in $\mathcal{I}_{k}$ ). That is $n\left(n_{k}-1\right) n_{0}\left(n_{0}-1\right)$ combinations. For the second situation, $i_{1}$ can take $n$ values, $i_{2}$ can take $n_{0}$ values, then $j_{1}$ and $j_{2}$ take values in all the data except into the two folds that contain $i_{1}$ and $i_{2}$ (since $j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}$ and $j_{1}=j_{3}, j_{2}=j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}$ ), that is $\left(n_{0}-n_{k}\right)\left(n_{0}-n_{k}-1\right)$. That is $n\left(n-n_{k}\right)\left(n_{0}-n_{k}\right)\left(n_{0}-n_{k}-1\right)$ combinations. Therefore, the total number of indices is equal to

$$
n n_{0}^{3}\left(\frac{K^{2}-3 K+3}{(K-1)^{2}}-2 n_{0}^{-1}+n_{0}^{-2}\right)
$$

- Case 2: $j_{1}=j_{4}, j_{2}=j_{3}$, and $i_{1} \neq i_{2}$. Then,

$$
E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]=E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right]
$$

The number of indices $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E}$ in this case is exactly the same as in the previous case, which is presented in (E-17).

Finally, note that

$$
\left|\sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cup \mathcal{E} \leq 3} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]\right| \leq 3^{6} n^{3}\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right) n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} M_{1}
$$

which follows by triangular inequality, (E-12), and by using that the number of elements in $\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}$ is lower or equal to $3^{6} n^{3}$ (for each 3 -tuple $(a, b, c) \in[n]^{3}$, consider the functions from the positions $\{1,2,3,4,5,6\}$ into the possible values $\{a, b, c\}$, the number of all these functions is $3^{4}$, while the number of 3 -tuple is $n^{3}$ ).

In what follows, I use the preliminary findings to calculate $I_{2}$ up to an error of size $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2}= & n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right] \\
\stackrel{(1)}{=} & n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right] \\
& +n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cup \mathcal{E} \leq 3} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right] \\
\stackrel{(2)}{=} & n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}-2} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}} E\left[\left(\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, l}\right)\left(\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, l}\right)\right]+O\left(n^{1-6 \varphi_{1}}\right) \\
\stackrel{(3)}{=} & n_{0}^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}\left(\frac{K^{2}-3 K+3}{(K-1)^{2}}-2 n_{0}^{-1}+n_{0}^{-2}\right) 2 E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right)\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right]+O\left(n^{1-6 \varphi_{1}}\right) \\
\stackrel{(4)}{=} & n_{0}^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}\left(\frac{K^{2}-3 K+3}{(K-1)^{2}}\right) G_{\delta}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by the derivations in (E-14) and (E-15), (2) holds by (E-18), (3) holds by (E-16) that computes the expected value and (E-17) that calculates the number of indices to consider, and (4) holds by definition of $G_{\delta}$ in (3.2), Assumption A.1, $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$, and since $6 \varphi_{1}-1>\zeta$. This completes the proof of Claim 1.2.

Claim 1.3: $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. First, claim 1.1 implies $I_{1}$ is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Second, claim 1.2 implies $I_{2}$ is $O\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $4 \varphi_{1}-1 \geq \zeta$. Finally, then $I_{3}$ is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ due to Cauchy-Schwartz (

$\left|I_{3}\right| \leq\left|I_{1}\right|^{1 / 2}\left|I_{2}\right|^{1 / 2}$ ). This completes the proof of Claim 1.3.

Claim 2: $E\left[I_{b, b}^{2}\right]=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following notation,

$$
\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{b, b}=b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-E\left[b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right]
$$

where by construction $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{b, b}\right]=0$. Denote $\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}=E\left[b_{n_{0}, j, i} \mid X_{i}\right]$. Note that if $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$, then

$$
\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{b, b}=b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}-E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}^{\top} H_{i} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right]
$$

Furthermore,

$$
n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left|\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i}^{b, b}\right|^{2}\right] \leq\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right) n_{0}^{3\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}
$$

which follows by C-S, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, and part (b.4) of Assumption 3.2, with $\tilde{C}_{2}=C_{2}\left(1+M^{1 / 4} / C_{0}\right)$. And, if $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$,

$$
n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left|\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{b, b}\right|^{2}\right] \leq\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right) n_{0}^{2\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}
$$

which holds by C-S, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, and part (b.1) of Assumption 3.2.
The previous notation can be used to rewrite $I_{b, b}$ as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[I_{b, b}^{2}\right] & =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{b, b}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j, j, i}^{b, b}+n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{b, b} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =I_{1}+I_{2}+2 I_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j, j, i}^{b, b}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& I_{2}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{b, b} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& I_{3}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{3} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} \sum_{j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i}^{b, b} I\left\{j_{3} \neq j_{4}\right\}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show that $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right), I_{2}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of Claim 2 .

Claim 2.1: $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following expansion,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1} & =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b}\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right] \\
& =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{E}=\left\{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in[n]^{4}: i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}, i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}, j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}, k_{1} \in[K], k_{2} \in[K]\right\}$, with $[n]$ denoting $\{1, \ldots, n\}$. Let $\mathcal{E}_{4} \subseteq[n]^{4}$ be the subset of indices with distinct entries. Let $\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3} \subset[n]^{4}$ be the subset of indices with at most three distinct entries.

Now, take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}$. It follows that

$$
E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]=0
$$

since $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$ are zero mean independent random variables.
Now, take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}$. Consider the following derivation,

$$
n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]\right| \leq\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right) n_{0}^{3\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}
$$

which follows by C-S and (E-19).
Therefore,

$$
\left|n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]\right| \leq n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4} 3^{4} n^{3}\left(p \tilde{C}_{2} / C_{0}\right) n_{0}^{3\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}
$$

which uses that $\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}$ has at most $3^{4} n^{3}$ elements (as in the proof of claim 1.1).
Using these two preliminary results, it follows that

$$
I_{1}=o\left(n^{1-6 \varphi_{1}}\right)
$$

since $\tilde{\tau}_{n_{0}}=o(1)$ and $n / 2 \leq n_{0} \leq n$. This completes the proof of Claim 2.2 since $6 \varphi_{1}-1>\zeta$.

Claim 2.2: $I_{2}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following expansion,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2} & =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{k_{1}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{3}, j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} I\left\{j_{3} \neq j_{4}\right\} \\
& =n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{E}=\left\{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in[n]^{6}: i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}, i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}} ; j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}} ; j_{3}, j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}} ; j_{1} \neq j_{2} ; j_{3} \neq\right.$ $\left.j_{4} ; k_{1}, k_{2} \in[K]\right\}$. Let $\mathcal{E}_{6} \subseteq[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with distinct entries. Let $\mathcal{E}_{5} \subseteq[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with exactly five distinct entries, meaning that two entries are identical while the remaining entries are distinct. Let $\mathcal{E}_{4} \subseteq[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with exactly four distinct entries. Let $\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3} \subset[n]^{6}$ be the subset of indices with at most three distinct entries. Note that $[n]^{6}=\mathcal{E}_{\leq 3} \cup \mathcal{E}_{4} \cup \mathcal{E}_{5} \cup \mathcal{E}_{6}$.

Note that for all $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E}_{6}$, it follows $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]=0$ since $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$ are independent zero mean random variables.

Now, take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$. There are three possible cases:

- Case 1: $j_{s}=j_{r}$ for some $s \in\{1,2\}$ and $r \in\{3,4\}$. Since all the sub-cases are similar, without loss of generality, take $(s, r)=(1,3)$. It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]\right| \stackrel{(1)}{\leq}\left|E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}\right]\right| \\
& +n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right] E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} \tilde{C} E\left[\left|\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)\right|^{2}\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right|^{2}\right]+n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} \tilde{C} E\left[E\left[\left|\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)\right|^{2}\left|X_{i_{1}}\right|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} E\left[\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right|^{4}\right]^{1 / 2}+n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{\leq} \tilde{C} n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} \tau_{n_{0}} M_{1}^{1 / 2}+n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality, LIE and definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$ when $j_{1}=j_{3}$ and $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$, (2) holds by part (e) of Assumption 3.1 with $\tilde{C}$ as a function of $\left(C_{0}, C_{2}, M, p\right)$ and part (b.3) of Assumption 3.2 with C-S, (3) holds by LIE and C-S, and (4) holds by parts (b.1) and (b.3) of Assumption 3.2.

- Case 2: $j_{s}=i_{2}$ for some $s \in\{1,2\}$ or $j_{r}=i_{1}$ for some $r \in\{3,4\}$. Since all the sub-cases are similar, take $s=1$. It follows that

$$
n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, j_{1}}^{b, b}\right]\right| \stackrel{(1)}{\leq}\left|E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{1}}^{\top} H_{j_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{1}}\right]\right|
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right] E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{1}}^{\top} H_{j_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{1}}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} \tilde{C} E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|^{4}\right]^{1 / 4} E\left[\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{1}}\right|^{4}\right]^{3 / 4}+n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} \tilde{C} n_{0}^{3\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right) / 4} \tau_{n_{0}}^{1 / 4} M_{1}^{3 / 4}+n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality, LIE, and definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$ when $j_{1}=i_{2}$ and $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$; (2) holds by part (e) of Assumption 3.1 with $\tilde{C}$ as a function of $\left(C_{0}, C_{2}, M, p\right)$, C-S, and part (b.3) of Assumption 3.2 with C-S; (3) holds by parts (b.3) and (b.4) of Assumption 3.2.

- Case 3: $i_{1}=i_{2}$. It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, j_{1}}^{b, b}\right]\right| & \stackrel{(1)}{\leq}\left|E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right]\right| \\
& +\left|E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right] E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} 2 \tilde{C} M_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality, LIE, and definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$ when $i_{1}=i_{2}$ and $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$; and (2) holds by part (e) of Assumption 3.1 with $\tilde{C}$ as a function of $\left(C_{0}, C_{2}, M, p\right)$, C-S, and part (b.3) of Assumption 3.2 with C-S.

Therefore, for the indices on $\mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right] \stackrel{(1)}{=} o\left(n^{1-2 \varphi_{1}-2 \varphi_{2}}\right)+o\left(n^{3 / 4-3 \varphi_{1} / 2-3 \varphi_{2}}\right)+O\left(n^{-4 \varphi_{2}}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since the number of elements of $\mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$ is lower than $5^{6} n^{5}$ and the preliminary findings in cases 1,2 , and 3 , and (2) holds since $2 \varphi_{1}+2 \varphi_{2}-1>\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2 \geq \zeta$, $3 \varphi_{1} / 2+3 \varphi_{2}-3 / 4>\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2 \geq \zeta$, and $4 \varphi_{2}>4 \varphi_{1}-1 \geq \zeta$.

Now, take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}$. There are three cases.

- Case 1: $j_{1}=j_{s}$ and $j_{2}=j_{r}$ for $\{r, s\}=\{3,4\}$. Without loss of generality, consider $(s, r)=(3,4)$. It follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq}\left|E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{1}}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right)\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right]\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right] E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} \tilde{C} E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right\| n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right\|\right]+n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} \tilde{C} E\left[E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|\left\|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right\| \mid X_{i_{1}}, X_{i_{2}}\right] E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right|\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right\| X_{i_{1}}, X_{i_{2}}\right]\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{\leq} \tilde{C} E\left[E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right] E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{2}}\right]\right]+n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{\leq} \tilde{C} E\left[E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right]^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} E\left[E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{2}}\right]^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}+n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1} \\
& \stackrel{(6)}{\leq} \tilde{C} n_{0}^{2\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}+n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality, LIE, and definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$ when $j_{1}=j_{3}, j_{2}=j_{4}$ and $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$; (2) holds by part (e) of Assumption 3.1 with $\tilde{C}$ as a function of $\left(C_{0}, C_{2}, M, p\right)$, C-S, and part (b.3) of Assumption 3.2 with C-S; (3) holds by LIE; (4) and (5) holds by C-S; and (6) holds by part (b.1) of Assumption 3.2 .

- Case 2: $j_{1}=j_{s}$ for $s \in\{3,4\}$ and $j_{2}=i_{2}$. Without loss of generality, $s=3$. It follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{0}^{-3 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]\right| \stackrel{(1)}{\leq}\left|E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{1}}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right)\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, j_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{j_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{2}}\right)\right]\right| \\
& +n_{0}^{-3 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right] E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{2}}^{\top} H_{j_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, j_{2}}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} \tilde{C} n_{0}^{9\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right) / 4} \tau_{n_{0}}^{3 / 4} M_{1}^{1 / 4}+\tilde{C} n_{0}^{-3 \varphi_{2}} M_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality, LIE, and definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$ when $j_{1}=j_{3}, j_{2}=i_{2}$ and $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$; and (2) holds by C-S and parts (b.3) and (b.4) of Assumption 3.2.

- Case 3: $j_{1}=j_{s}$ for $s \in\{3,4\}$ and $i_{1}=i_{2}$. Without loss of generality, consider $s=3$. It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{4}, i_{1}}^{b, b}\right]\right| \stackrel{(1)}{\leq}\left|E\left[\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right]\right| \\
& +n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right] E\left[\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} \tilde{C} n_{0}^{1-2 \varphi_{1}} \tau_{n_{0}} M_{1}^{1 / 2}+n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} \tilde{C} M_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangular inequality, LIE and definition of $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}$

when $j_{1}=j_{3}$ and $i_{1}=i_{2}$ and $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}$; and (2) holds by the same derivations presented in Case 1 when $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{5}$; therefore, it is omitted.

Therefore, for the indices on $\mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}$, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right] \stackrel{(1)}{=} o\left(n^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}\right)+o\left(n^{5 / 4-9 \varphi_{1} / 2-\varphi_{2}}\right)+O\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}-2 \varphi_{2}}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since the number of elements of $\mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{4}$ is lower than $4^{6} n^{4}$ and the preliminary findings in cases 1,2 , and 3 ; and (2) holds since $4 \varphi_{1}-1 \geq \zeta, 9 \varphi_{1} / 2+\varphi_{2}-5 / 4>\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2 \geq$ $\zeta$, and $2 \varphi_{1}+2 \varphi_{2}>\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2 \geq \zeta$.

Now, take $\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}, j_{3}, j_{4}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}$. Similar to the proof of Claim 2.1 but using (E-20) instead of (E-19), it follows that

$$
\left|n^{-1} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}-4} \sum_{\left(i_{1}, i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{E} \cap \mathcal{E}_{\leq 3}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{b, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{b, b}\right]\right|=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)
$$

Finally, using (E-21), (E-22), and (E-23), it follows that $I_{2}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. This completes the proof of Claim 2.2 .

Claim 2.3: $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. This result is a consequence of C-S and Claims 2.1 and 2.2.

Claim 3: $E\left[I_{l, b}^{2}\right]=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following notation,

$$
\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, b}=\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} H_{i} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}
$$

where it holds $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, b}\right]=0$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2.
Furthermore,

$$
n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left|\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, b}\right|^{2}\right] \leq \tilde{C} n_{0}^{2\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}^{1 / 2} M_{1}^{1 / 2}
$$

which follows by C-S, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, and parts (b.2) and (b.4) of Assumption 3.2 , with $\tilde{C}$ function of $\left(C_{2}, M, C_{0}, p\right)$.

The previous notation can be used to rewrite $E\left[I_{l, b}^{2}\right]$ as follows

$$
=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, b}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j, i}^{l, b}+n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, b} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =I_{1}+I_{2}+2 I_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j, j, i}^{l, b}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& I_{2}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, b} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& I_{3}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j, j, i}^{l, b}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i}^{l, b} I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show that $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right), I_{2}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of Claim 2 .

Claim 3.1: $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following expansion,

$$
I_{1}=n^{-1} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-2 \varphi_{2}-3} \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]
$$

Now, $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]$ is calculated under the two possible cases based on the indices $\left(i_{1}, j_{1}, i_{2}, j_{2}\right)$.

- Case 1: $\left(i_{1}, j_{1}\right)$ and $\left(i_{2}, j_{2}\right)$ have no element in common. Then $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]$ is zero since $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, b}$ are independent zero mean random variables.
- Case 2: $\left(i_{1}, j_{1}\right)$ and $\left(i_{2}, j_{2}\right)$ have at least one element in common. In this case, there are at most $3^{4} n^{3}$ possible indices. Moreover, due to (E-24) and C-S, it follows

$$
\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]\right| \leq \tilde{C} n_{0}^{3\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right) / 2} \tau_{n_{0}}^{(1 / 2)} n_{0}^{\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} M_{1}^{1 / 2}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{1}\right| & \leq n^{-1} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-3} 3^{4} n^{3} \tilde{C} n_{0}^{2\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}^{1 / 2} M_{1}^{1 / 2} \\
& =o\left(n^{1-6 \varphi_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which is sufficient to conclude that $I_{1}$ is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $6 \varphi_{1}-1>4 \varphi_{1}-1 \geq \zeta$. This completes the proof of Claim 3.1.

Claim 3.2: $I_{2}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following expansion,
$I_{2}=n^{-1} \sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-2 \varphi_{2}-3} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{3}, j_{4} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} I\left\{j_{3} \neq j_{4}\right\}$

Now, $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]$ is calculated under four possible cases based on the indices.

- Case 1: all indices are different. Then , $E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]$ equals zero since $\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{l, b}$ and $\Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, b}$ are independent zero mean random variables.
- Case 2: there are exactly five different indices. Then, consider the four different subcases:
$-j_{1}=j_{3}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]\right| & =\left|E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}\right]\right| \\
& \leq \hat{C} E\left[\left|\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right|\left|\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right|\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}\right|\right] \\
& \leq \hat{C} E\left[E\left[\left|\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right]\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right|^{2}\right] \\
& =O(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

which holds by C-S, LIE, and part (b.1) and (b.3) of Assumption 3.2. Since there are at most $5^{6} n^{5}$ terms, it follows these terms contributed to $I_{2}$ with $O\left(n^{1-2 \varphi_{1}-2 \varphi_{2}}\right)$ which is larger than $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $2 \varphi_{1}+2 \varphi_{1}-1>\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}-1 / 2 \geq \zeta$.
$-j_{1}=j_{4}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{1}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right] & =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right] \\
& =E\left[E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \mid X_{j_{1}}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{2}}, W_{j_{3}}\right] H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right] \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which holds due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2.
$-j_{1}=i_{2}$, then

$$
E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, j_{1}}^{l, b}\right]=E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, j_{1}}^{\top} H_{j_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{4}, j_{1}}\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, j_{1}}^{\top} \mid W_{i_{1}}, W_{j_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}, W_{j_{4}}\right] H_{j_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{4}, j_{1}}\right] \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

- $i_{1}=i_{2}$, then $j_{3}$ is different than all and the previous argument used for $j_{1}=i_{2}$ applies and implies

$$
E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]=0
$$

- Case 3: there are exactly four different indices. Then
- if $j_{2}$ or $j_{4}$ is different than all, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{4}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]\right| & =\left|E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}\right]\right| \\
& =\tilde{C} E\left[\left|\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{1}}\right|\left|\delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, i_{2}}\right|\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i_{2}}\right|\right] \\
& =O(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

which holds by C-S, LIE, and parts (b.1) and (b.3) of Assumption 3.2. Since there are at most $4^{6} n^{4}$ terms, it follows these terms, in this case, contributed to $I_{2}$ with $O\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}-2 \varphi_{2}}\right)$, which is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $2 \varphi_{1}+2 \varphi_{2}>4 \varphi_{1}-1$.

- if $j_{1}=j_{4}$ and $j_{2}=j_{3}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, j_{1}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right] & =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right] \\
& =E\left[E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \mid X_{j_{1}}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}, W_{i_{2}}\right] H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right]\right. \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which follows by part (a) of Assumption 3.2.

- if $j_{2}=j_{3}$ and $i_{1}=j_{4}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{2}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right] & =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} b_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}\right] \\
& =E\left[E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \mid X_{j_{1}}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}, W_{i_{2}}\right] H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} b_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}\right]\right. \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which follows by part (a) of Assumption 3.2.

- if $j_{1}=j_{3}$ and $j_{2}=j_{4}$, then

$$
n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}}\left|E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{l, b}\right]\right|=\left|E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} H_{i_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right]\right|
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq \tilde{C} E\left[E\left[\left|\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right] E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right]\right] \\
& \leq \tilde{C} E\left[E\left[\left|\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right]^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} E\left[E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}}\right|^{2} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right]^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq \tilde{C} M_{1}^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{\left(1-2 \varphi_{1}\right)} \tau_{n_{0}}^{1 / 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

which holds due to C-S, LIE, part (b.1) of Assumption 3.2. Since there are at most $4^{6} n^{4}$ terms, it follows these terms contributed to $I_{2}$ with $o\left(n^{1-4 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, which is $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ since $4 \varphi_{1}-1 \geq \zeta$.
$-j_{1}=i_{2}$ and $j_{2}=j_{4}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
