E\left[\Gamma_{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{1}}^{l, b} \Gamma_{j_{3}, j_{2}, j_{1}}^{l, b}\right] & =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, j_{1}}^{\top} H_{j_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, j_{1}}\right] \\
& =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} H_{i_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{1}} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{3}, j_{1}}^{\top} \mid X_{j_{3}}, W_{i_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}, W_{j_{1}}\right] H_{j_{1}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, j_{1}}\right] \\
& =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which holds due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2.

- Case 4: there are exactly three different indices. All the terms in this case contributed to $I_{2}$ with $o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ by a similar argument as Case 2 in the proof of Claim 3.1.

All the previous cases imply that $I_{2}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, which completes the proof of Claim 3.2.

Claim 3.3: $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. This result is a consequence of C-S and Claims 3.1 and 3.2.

Part 3: It follows by Cauchy-Schwartz, using part 2 of this proposition and part 1 of Proposition C.2.
Part 4: It follows by Cauchy-Schwartz, using part 2 of this proposition and part 2 of Proposition C.3.

# E. 7 Proof of Proposition C. 5 

Proof. For $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$, denote $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{b}+\Delta_{i}^{l}$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{i}^{l}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \delta_{n_{0}, j, i} \\
& \Delta_{i}^{b}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}=\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)$ and $b_{n_{0}, j, i}=b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{j}, X_{i}\right)$, and $\delta_{n_{0}}$ and $b_{n_{0}}$ are functions satisfying Assumption 3.2.

Part 1: Consider the following decomposition

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right] & =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}+\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& =n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right]+E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& =I_{1}+I_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{l}+\Delta_{i}^{b}$. Claim 1.1 below shows that $I_{1}=0$, while Claim 1.2 shows $I_{2}=\left(G_{b}^{l} / 2\right) n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}}+o\left(n^{-\varphi_{2}}\right)$.
Claim 1: $I_{1}=0$. To see this, consider the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{1} & =n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right) \delta_{n, j, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right) E\left[\delta_{n, j, i_{2}}^{\top} \mid W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}\right] \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right) \delta_{n, j, i_{2}}^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0} \mid X_{i_{2}}, W_{j}\right]\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{i}^{l}$, (2) holds by the law of iterative expectations, (3) holds since $E\left[\delta_{n, j, i_{2}}^{\top} \mid W_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}\right]=0$ when $i_{1} \neq j$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2 and by the law of iterative expectations, and (4) holds by the Neyman orthogonality condition implied by part (b) of Assumption 3.1.
Claim 2: $I_{2}=\left(G_{b}^{l} / 2\right) n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}}+o\left(n^{-\varphi_{2}}\right)$. To see this, consider the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2} & =n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right) b_{n_{0}, j, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right) b_{n_{0}, j, i_{2}}^{\top} E\left[\partial_{n} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0} \mid X_{i_{2}}, W_{i_{1}}, X_{j}\right]\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) E\left[b_{n_{0}, j, i_{2}}^{\top} \mid W_{i_{2}}\right] \partial_{n} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right) \tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i_{2}}\right) \partial_{n} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}}\left(G_{b}^{l} / 2\right)+o\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{i}^{b}$, (2) holds by the law of iterative expectations, (3) holds since $E\left[\partial_{n} m_{i_{2}} / J_{0} \mid X_{i_{2}}, W_{i_{1}}, X_{j}\right]=0$ when $i_{1} \neq i_{2}$ due to the Neyman orthogonality condition implied by part (b) of Assumption 3.1 and the law of iterative expectations, (4) holds by definitions of $\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}=E\left[b_{n_{0}, j, i} \mid X_{i}\right]$ which is equal to $E\left[b_{n_{0}, j, i} \mid W_{i}\right]$, and (5) holds by definition of $G_{b}^{l}$ in (A-7) and Assumption A.1.

Part 2: Consider the following decomposition,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\mathcal{T}_{n}^{*} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right] & =E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}\right)\right)\right] \\
& =I_{1}+2 I_{2}+I_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)\right)\right] \\
& I_{2}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)\right)\right] \\
& I_{3}=E\left[\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{b}\right)\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In what follows, I show that $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right), I_{2}=\left(G_{b} / 2\right) n_{0}^{1 / 2-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$.

Claim 1: $I_{1}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
I_{1} \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right)\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\stackrel{(2)}{=} & n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& +2 n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& =n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)\right]+2 n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} O\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{i}^{l}$, (2) holds since $i_{1} \notin\left\{i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right\}$ implies

$$
E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right)\right]=0
$$

which follows since $m_{i_{1}}$ is a zero mean random variable independent of $W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{1}}$ and $W_{j_{2}}$, (3) holds since $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$ implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] & =0 \\
E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] & =0 \\
E\left[\left(m_{j_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\delta_{n, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which follows by the law of iterative expectations and noting $E\left[\delta_{n, j_{2}, i} \mid W_{i}, W_{j_{1}}\right]=0$ and $E\left[\delta_{n, j_{1}, i} \mid W_{i}, W_{j_{2}}\right]=0$ (due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2), and (4) holds by Holder's inequality, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, and part (a) of Assumption 3.2.

Claim 2: $I_{2}=\left(G_{b} / 2\right) n_{0}^{1 / 2-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{2} & \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-3 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}+1 / 2} E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& -n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}-1 / 2} E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-1 / 2} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{=}\left(G_{b} / 2\right) n_{0}^{1 / 2-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}}+o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{1, i}^{l}$ and $\Delta_{1, i}^{b}$, (2) holds since $i_{1} \notin\left\{i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right\}$ implies

$$
E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right)\right]
$$

by using that $m_{i_{1}}$ is zero mean and independent of $W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{1}}$, and $W_{j_{2}}$, (3) holds by definition of $\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}=E\left[b_{n_{0}, j, i} \mid X_{i}\right]$, and since $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$ and the law of iterative expectations implies

$$
\left(m_{\ell} / J_{0}\right) E\left[\left(\delta_{n, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} \mid W_{i}, W_{j_{2}}\right] H_{i_{2}}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)=0
$$

for $\ell=i, j_{2}$ by using part (a) of Assumption 3.2, (4) holds by the law of the iterative expectations,

$$
\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right) E\left[\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} \mid W_{i}, X_{j}\right] H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)=0
$$

and by parts (a) of Assumption 3.2, and (5) holds by definition of $G_{b}$ in (A-6) and Assumption A. 1 and because

$$
n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-1 / 2} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(\delta_{n, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq C n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}-1 / 2} E\left[\left|m_{j} / J_{0}\right|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} E\left[\left\|\delta_{n, j, i}\right\|^{4}\right]^{1 / 4} E\left[\left|\left|n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right\|^{4}\right]\right. \\
& =O\left(n^{-\varphi_{1}-1 / 2}\right) \times O(1) \times O\left(n_{0}^{1 / 4-\varphi_{1} / 2}\right) \times o\left(n_{0}^{3 / 4-3 \varphi_{1} / 2}\right) \\
& =o\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \varphi_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the inequality uses part (d) of Assumption 3.1 and Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, and the equalities follows by part (b) of Assumption 3.2. The proof of the claim is completed since $\zeta<1 / 2-3 \varphi_{1}$ whenever $\varphi_{1}<1 / 2$.

Claim 3: $I_{3}=o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{4} & \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i_{1}=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right)^{\top} H_{i_{2}}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{i} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}-2} \sum_{j_{1}, j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j_{2}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\tilde{b}_{n_{0}, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}\right)\right] I\left\{j_{1} \neq j_{2}\right\} \\
& +n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(m_{j} / J_{0}\right)\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)^{\top} H_{i}\left(n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{=} O\left(n^{-2 \varphi_{2}}\right)+o\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \varphi_{1}}\right)+o\left(n^{1 / 2-\varphi_{1}-\varphi_{2}}\right)+o\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \varphi_{1}}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{=} o\left(n^{-\zeta}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\Delta_{1, i}^{b}$, (2) holds since $i_{1} \notin\left\{j_{1}, j_{2}, i_{2}\right\}$ implies

$$
E\left[\left(m_{i_{1}} / J_{0}\right)\left(\left(b_{n, j_{1}, i_{2}}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{n}^{2} m_{i_{2}} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(b_{n, j_{2}, i_{2}}\right)\right)\right]=0
$$

by using that $m_{i_{1}}$ is zero mean and independent of $W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{1}}$, and $W_{j_{2}}$; (3) holds by the law of iterative expectations; (4) holds by parts (b) and (c) of Assumption 3.2, parts (c) and (e) of Assumption 3.1, part (b.1) of Assumption 3.2, and Holder's inequality; and (5) holds since $\zeta<1 / 2-3 \varphi_{1}$ and $\zeta<2 \varphi_{2}$ (because $\varphi_{1}<1 / 2$ and $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$ ).

# E. 8 Proof of Lemma C. 1 

Proof. It is sufficient to show the result for the case when $\delta_{n_{0}}$ and $b_{n_{0}}$ are real-valued functions since for any $x=\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{p}\right) \in \mathbf{R}^{p}$ it holds $\|x\|^{4}=\left(\sum_{\ell=1}^{p} x_{\ell}^{2}\right)^{2} \leq p \sum_{\ell=1}^{p}\left|x_{\ell}\right|^{4}$. In the proof, I use that $E\left[\left(\sum_{\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} Z_{\ell}\right)^{4}\right] \leq n_{0} E\left[Z_{\ell}^{4}\right]+3 n_{0}^{2} E\left[Z_{\ell}^{2}\right]^{2}$, which holds for zero mean i.i.d. random variables $Z_{\ell}$.
Part 1: Fix $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ and denote $Z_{\ell}=\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{\ell}, X_{i}\right)$ for any $\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}$. Conditional on $X_{i}$, it holds that $\left\{Z_{\ell}: \ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ is a zero mean i.i.d. sequence of random variables due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2. Therefore,

$$
E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} Z_{\ell}\right|^{4} \mid X_{i}\right] \leq n_{0}^{-2-4 \varphi_{1}}\left(n_{0} E\left[Z_{\ell}^{4} \mid X_{i}\right]+3 n_{0}^{2} E\left[Z_{\ell}^{2} \mid X_{i}\right]^{2}\right)
$$

Using the previous inequality and the law of iterative expectations, it follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} Z_{\ell}\right|^{4}\right] & \leq n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}}\left(n_{0}^{-1} E\left[Z_{\ell}^{4}\right]+3 E\left[E\left[Z_{\ell}^{2} \mid X_{i}\right]^{2}\right]\right) \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}}\left(n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} M_{1}+3 M_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by parts (b.1) and (b.2) of Assumption 3.2, and the definition of $Z_{\ell}$. Taking $C \geq 4 M_{1}$ completes the proof of part 1.
Part 2: Fix $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ and denote $Z_{\ell}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}}\left(b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{\ell}, X_{i}\right)-\tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i}\right)\right)$ for any $\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}$, where $\tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i}\right)=E\left[b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{\ell}, X_{i}\right) \mid X_{i}\right]$. As in part $1,\left\{Z_{\ell}: \ell \notin \mathcal{I}\right\}$ conditional on $X_{i}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random variables. Therefore,
$E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(Z_{\ell}+n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i}\right)\right)\right|^{4}\right] \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} 2^{3} E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} Z_{\ell}\right|^{4}\right]+2^{3} E\left[\left|n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{\ell \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} \tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i}\right)\right|^{4}\right]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} 8 n_{0}^{-2}\left(n_{0}^{-1} E\left[Z_{\ell}^{4}\right]+3 E\left[E\left[Z_{\ell}^{2} \mid X_{i}\right]^{2}\right]\right)+8 n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} E\left[\left|\tilde{b}_{n_{0}}\left(X_{i}\right)\right|^{4}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} 8 n_{0}^{-6 \varphi_{1}} \tau_{n_{0}}+24 n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{1}} \tau_{n_{0}}+8 n_{0}^{-4 \varphi_{2}} M_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)), (2) holds by the same arguments as in part 1, and (3) holds by part (b.1), (b.3) and (b.4) of Assumption 3.2. Taking $C \geq 32+8 M_{1}$ completes the proof of part 2 .

# E. 9 Proof of Lemma C. 2 

Proof. For $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$, denote $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{b}+\Delta_{i}^{l}$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{i}^{l}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \delta_{n_{0}, j, i} \\
& \Delta_{i}^{b}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}=\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)$ and $b_{n_{0}, j, i}=b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{j}, X_{i}\right)$, and $\delta_{n_{0}}$ and $b_{n_{0}}$ are functions satisfying Assumption 3.2. In what follows, the results are proved for any given sequence $K$ that diverges to infinity as $n$ diverges to infinity, which is sufficient to guarantee the results of this lemma.
Part 1: Using Assumption 3.2, it follows

$$
n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\bar{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}=I_{1}+I_{2}+I_{3}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \\
& I_{2}=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \\
& I_{3}=n^{-1} n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \hat{R}_{1}\left(X_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}
\end{aligned}
$$

and $n_{0}=((K-1) / K) n$.
Claim 1: $I_{1}=O_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2-\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. I first show that $E\left[I_{1}\right]=0$ (claim 1.1). I then show that $E\left[I_{1}^{2}\right]=O\left(n^{-1-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$ (claim 1.2), which is sufficient to conclude the claim.

Claim 1.1: $E\left[I_{1}\right]=0$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[I_{1}\right] & =n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right] \\
& =n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \mid X_{i},\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)\right]\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \mid X_{i},\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)\right]\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since $\Delta_{i}^{l}=\Delta_{1}^{l}\left(X_{i}\right)$ is a function of $X_{i}$ and the data $\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)$ used to estimate $\hat{\eta}_{k}(\cdot)$, and (2) holds by part (b) in Assumption 3.1.
Claim 1.2: $E\left[I_{1}^{2}\right]=O\left(n^{-1-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. Recall that I use the following notation $\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}=$ $\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)$ and $\Delta_{i}^{l}=\Delta_{1}^{l}\left(X_{i}\right)=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \delta_{n_{0}, j, i}$ for $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$. To show $E\left[I_{1}^{2}\right]=$ $O\left(n^{-1-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$, consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[I_{1}^{2}\right] & \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-2} \sum_{i_{1}, i_{2}=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n^{-2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right]+n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} n^{-2} \sum_{i_{1} \neq i_{2}}^{n}\left|E\left[\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right]+\frac{(n-1) n^{-1}}{n_{0}^{1+2 \varphi_{1}}}\left|E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right]\right| \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{\leq} n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right]+(n-1) n^{-1} n_{0}^{-(1+2 \varphi_{1})} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z}\right)^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right)^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \\
& =n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}-1} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right]+(n-1) n^{-1} n_{0}^{-(1+2 \varphi_{1})} E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $I_{1}$, (2) holds by triangular inequality, (3) holds by (E-25) and (E-26) presented below, (4) holds by Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, and (5) holds by the derivations presented next,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right] & =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} E\left[\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{\top}\right) \mid X_{i}, W_{j}\right] \delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}^{\top} E\left[\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{\top}\right) \mid X_{i}\right] \delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} E\left[\left\|\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}\right\|^{2}\right] C_{1} \times p
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\stackrel{(3)}{\leq} M_{1}^{1 / 2} C_{1} \times p
$$

where (1) holds since $i \neq j$, (2) holds by part (d) of Assumption 3.1 and Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)), and (3) holds by Jensen's inequality (e.g., $E\left[\left\|\delta\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \leq$ $E\left[\left\|\delta\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)\right\|^{4}\right]^{1 / 4}$ ) and part (b) of Assumption 3.2. Note these derivations complete the proof of claim 1.2 .

The previous derivations used the following claims:

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right] & =n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\delta\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \delta\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right] \\
E\left[\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] & =n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] I\left\{k_{1} \neq k_{2}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

To show (E-25), consider the following derivations.

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\left(\Delta_{i}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right] & =n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} E\left[\delta\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \delta\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds due to the following: if $j_{1} \neq j_{2}$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right] & =E\left[E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} \mid W_{i}, W_{j_{2}}\right] \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right] \\
& =E\left[E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i}^{\top} \mid X_{i}\right] \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by definition of $\delta_{n_{0}}$ in part (a) of Assumption 3.2.
To show (E-26), consider $i_{1} \neq i_{2}$ where $i_{1} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}$ and $i_{2} \in \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}$, therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(\Delta_{i_{1}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z}\left(\Delta_{i_{2}}^{l}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] & =n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j_{1} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{1}}} \sum_{j_{2} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k_{2}}} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n_{0}^{-1} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, i_{2}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, i_{1}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] I\left\{k_{1} \neq k_{2}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since $k_{1}=k_{2}$ implies $j_{2} \neq i_{1}$ and $j_{1} \neq i_{2}$, and because the conditions $j_{2} \neq i_{1}$ or $j_{1} \neq i_{2}$ imply that $E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right]$ is zero. To see this, suppose $j_{2} \neq i_{1}$ and consider the following derivations,

$$
E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right]=E\left[E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z} \mid X_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}\right]\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \mid X_{i_{1}}, W_{i_{2}}, W_{j_{1}}, W_{j_{2}}\right] \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[\delta_{n_{0}, j_{1}, i_{1}}^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{1}}^{z} \mid X_{i_{1}}\right] \delta_{n_{0}, j_{2}, i_{2}}^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i_{2}}^{z}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since $i_{1} \notin\left\{i_{2}, j_{1}, j_{2}\right\}$ (since $i_{1} \neq j_{2}$ ) and (2) holds by part (b) in Assumption 3.1. Similar derivations conclude the same for $j_{1} \neq i_{2}$.

Claim 2: $I_{2}=O\left(n^{-1 / 2-\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. Define $X^{(n)}=\left\{X_{i}: 1 \leq i \leq n\right\}$. I first show $E\left[I_{2} \mid\right.$ $\left.X^{(n)}\right]=0$. I then show $E\left[I_{2}^{2}\right] \leq n^{-1} E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2}\right] C_{1} p$, which is sufficient to conclude due to Lemma C. 1 that implies that $E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2}\right]$ is $O\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$ due to Cauchy-Schwartz.

The first part holds due to the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[I_{2} \mid X^{(n)}\right] & =E\left[n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \mid X^{(n)}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \mid X^{(n)}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} E\left[\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z} \mid X_{i}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since $\Delta_{i}^{b}$ is function of $X^{(n)}$ and $\Delta_{i}^{b}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{i_{0} \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} b\left(X_{i_{0}}, X_{i}\right)$ for $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ due to part (a) of Assumption 3.2, (2) holds since the observations are i.i.d., and (3) follows due to part (b) of Assumption 3.1.

To prove that $E\left[I_{2}^{2}\right] \leq n^{-1} E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2}\right] C_{1} p$, first note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[I_{2}^{2} \mid X^{(n)}\right] & =E\left[\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2} \mid X^{(n)}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[n^{-2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2} \mid X^{(n)}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{-2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} E\left[\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{\top} \mid X_{i}\right] \Delta_{i}^{b} \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n^{-2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2} C_{1} \times p
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds because $E\left[\left(\left(\Delta_{i}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)\left(\left(\Delta_{j}^{b}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{j}^{z}\right) \mid X^{(n)}\right]=0$ when $i \neq j$ (since $\Delta_{i}^{b}$ and

$\Delta_{j}^{b}$ are functions of $X^{(n)}$, and part (b) of Assumption 3.1), (2) holds since $\Delta_{i}^{b}$ and $\Delta_{j}^{b}$ are functions of $X^{(n)}$ and the observations are i.i.d., and (3) holds by part (d) of Assumption 3.1. Then,

$$
E\left[E\left[I_{2}^{2} \mid X^{(n)}\right]\right] \leq E\left[n^{-2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2} C_{1} \times p\right]=n^{-1} E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2}\right] C_{1} p
$$

which completes the proof of this claim.
Claim 3: $I_{3}=O_{p}\left(n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. Algebra shows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{3}\right| & =\left|n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \hat{R}_{1}\left(X_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right| \\
& \leq n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{R}_{1}\left(X_{i}\right)\right\|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right\|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \times O_{p}(1) \times\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right\|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \times O_{p}(1) \times O_{p}(1) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} O_{p}\left(n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by part (c) of Assumption 3.2, (2) holds by the law of large numbers, Jensen's inequality (e.g., $\left.\left(E\left[\left\|\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right\|^{2}\right]\right] \leq E\left[\left\|\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right\|^{4}\right]^{1 / 2}\right)$, and part (c) of Assumption 3.1, and (3) holds since $n / 2 \leq n \leq n$
Part 2: By Taylor approximation and mean-value theorem (since $\psi^{z}(w, \eta)$ is twice continuously differentiable on $\eta$ by Assumption 3.1), it follows

$$
\hat{\psi}_{i}^{z}-\psi_{i}^{z}=\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{z}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)
$$

where $\partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{z}=\partial_{\eta}^{2} \psi^{z}\left(W_{i}, \eta\right) \mid_{\eta=\hat{\eta}_{i}}$ for some $\hat{\eta}_{i}$ (due to mean-value theorem). Using this

$$
\begin{aligned}
n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{z}-\psi_{i}^{z}\right) & =n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}+\frac{1}{2} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{z}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} O_{p}\left(n^{-\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}-1 / 2}\right)+\frac{1}{2} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{z}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds due to Part 1, and (2) holds due to the derivations presented next,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{m}_{i}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)\right| \leq n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta}^{2} \hat{m}_{i}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)\right| \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2} C_{2} \times p \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds due to part (e) of Assumption 3.1 and Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)), and (2) holds due to part 4 of Lemma C.4.

Part 3: It follows from part 1, by using that $\partial_{\eta} m_{i}=\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{b}-\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{a} \theta_{0}$ and $\left|\theta_{0}\right| \leq M_{1}^{1 / 4} / C_{0}$ (due to parts (a) and (c) of Assumptions 3.1 and the representation of $\theta_{0}$ as a ratio of expected values in (2.3)).

Part 4: By Taylor expansion and mean value theorem,

$$
\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}=\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i}+\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} m_{i} / 2\right)\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)+\tilde{r}_{i}
$$

where $\tilde{r}_{i}$ is the Lagrange's remainder error term (since $m$ is three-times continuous differentiable on $\eta$ by assumption on $\psi^{z}$ ). Therefore,

$$
\left|\tilde{r}_{i}\right| \leq(1 / 6) p^{3 / 2} C_{3}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{3}
$$

where the bound follows by part (e) of Assumption 3.1, Jensen's inequality, and the definition of Euclidean norm. It follows

$$
n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{m}_{i}-m_{i}\right) / J_{0}=I_{1}+I_{2}+I_{3}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0} \\
& I_{2}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} m_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right) \\
& I_{3}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \tilde{r}_{i} / J_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

In the claims below I show that $I_{1}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right), I_{2}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, and $I_{3}=o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of part 4. Furthermore, if Assumption 3.3 holds, then Proposition C. 5 implies $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \inf _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[n^{2 \varphi_{1}-1} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}\right]>0$; and if Assumption A. 1 holds, then Proposition C. 3 implies $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \inf _{K \leq n} \operatorname{Var}\left[n^{\varphi_{1}} \mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}\right]>0$.

Claim 1: $I_{1}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}+O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. By part (a) of Assumption 3.2, it follows

$$
I_{1}=I_{1,1}+I_{1,2}
$$

where $\hat{R}_{i}=\hat{R}\left(X_{i}\right)$ for $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1,1}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0} \\
& I_{1,2}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} \hat{R}_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} m_{i} / J_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

By definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$ in (A-3), it follows that $I_{1,1}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{l}$. Since $\partial_{\eta} m_{i}=\partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{b}-\theta_{0} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{a}$ and $\left|\theta_{0}\right| \leq M^{1 / 4} / C_{0}$, it follows that $I_{1,2}$ is $O_{p}\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$ due to proof of Claim 3 in Part 1 of this lemma.

Claim 2: $I_{2}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}+O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. By part (a) of Assumption 3.2, it follows

$$
I_{2}=I_{2,1}+2 I_{2,2}+I_{2,3}
$$

where $\hat{R}_{i}=\hat{R}\left(X_{i}\right)$ for $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{2,1}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} m_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(\Delta_{i}\right) \\
& I_{2,2}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\Delta_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} m_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} \hat{R}_{i}\right) \\
& I_{2,3}=n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} \hat{R}_{i}\right)^{\top}\left(\partial_{\eta}^{2} m_{i} /\left(2 J_{0}\right)\right)\left(n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} \hat{R}_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By definition of $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$ in (3.12), it follows that $I_{2,1}=\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$. In what follows, I prove claims that imply $I_{2, j}=o_{p}\left(n^{-\zeta}\right)$ for $j=2,3$ using that $\zeta<3 \varphi_{1}-1 / 2$ since $\varphi_{1}<1 / 2$, which is sufficient to complete the proof of claim 2 .

Claim 2.1: $I_{2,2}=O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. To see this, consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{2,2}\right| & \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n^{1 / 2} \times p C_{2}\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\Delta_{i}\right\| \times\left\|n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \hat{R}_{i}\right\|\right) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \times p C_{2}\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\Delta_{i}\right\|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \times\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} n^{1 / 2} n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \times O_{p}\left(n^{-\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right) \times O_{p}(1) \\
& =O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by triangle inequality, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, Jensen's inequality, and definition of Euclidean norm, (2) holds by Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, (3) holds by Lemma C. 1 and by part (c) of Assumption 3.2 and Markov's inequality.

Claim 2.2: $I_{2,3}=O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-4 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. The proof is similar to Claim 2.1; therefore, it is omitted.

Claim 3: $I_{3}=O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. Using (E-27), it follows

$$
\left|I_{3}\right| \leq(1 / 6) p^{3 / 2} C_{3} / J_{0} n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{3}
$$

In what follows, I prove that $n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{3}$ is $O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \varphi_{1}}\right)$.
By part (a) of Assumption 3.2 and since $\varphi_{1} \leq \varphi_{2}$, it follows

$$
\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}=\Delta_{i}+n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \hat{R}_{i}
$$

where $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{l}+\Delta_{i}^{h}$ and $\hat{R}_{i}=\hat{R}\left(X_{i}\right)$. Using triangle inequality and Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)) in the previous expression, it follows

$$
\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{3} \leq 2^{2}\left(\left\|\Delta_{i}\right\|^{3}+n_{0}^{-6 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\left\|\hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{3}\right)
$$

which implies

$$
n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{3} \leq 2^{2}\left(I_{3,1}+I_{3,2}\right)
$$

where

$$
I_{3,1}=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\Delta_{i}\right\|^{3}
$$

$$
I_{3,2}=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} n_{0}^{-6 \varphi_{1}}\left\|\hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{3}
$$

To complete the proof of claim 3 , it is sufficient to show $I_{3,1}=O_{p}\left(n^{-3 \varphi_{1}}\right)$ and $I_{3,2}=$ $O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-6 \varphi_{1}}\right)$, since they imply $n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{3}$ is $O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-3 \varphi_{1}}\right)$.

Claim 3.1: $I_{3,1}=O_{p}\left(n^{-3 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. The proof is a direct result of Lemma C. 1 and Markov's inequality; therefore, it is omitted.

Claim 3.2: $I_{3,2}=O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-6 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. Consider the following derivations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I_{3,2} & \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} n^{1 / 2} n^{-6 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right)^{3 / 2} \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n^{1 / 2} \times n^{-6 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \times O_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)), and (2) holds by part (c) of Assumption 3.2 with Markov's inequality. This completes the proof of claim 3.3.

Claim 1 and Claim 2 in the proof of Part 1 imply that $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{t}$ is $O_{p}\left(n^{-\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$. By the same argument used in the proof of Part 2 to bound the non-linear expression (but using Lemma E. 8 instead of part 4 of Lemma C.4), it follows that $\mathcal{T}_{n, K}^{n l}$ is $O_{p}\left(n^{1 / 2-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)$.

# E. 10 Proof of Lemma C. 3 

Proof. In what follows, the results are proved for any given sequence $K$ that diverges to infinity as $n$ diverges to infinity, which is sufficient to guarantee the result of this lemma.
Part 1: The proof of (C-3) has two steps. The first step shows

$$
E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{s}\right)^{2}\right] \leq C n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}
$$

for some positive constant $C=C\left(p, C_{1}, M_{1}, M_{2}\right)$. The second step shows

$$
E\left[\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{s}\right)^{2}\right] \leq C K n^{-1 / 2} n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}+1 / 2}
$$

which is sufficient to prove (C-3) by using Markov's inequality and $1 / 2<2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}$.

Step 1: Consider the following derivation

$$
E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2} \mid\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)\right]
$$

which is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} E\left[n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2} \mid\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} E\left[\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi^{z}\right)\left(\partial_{\eta} \psi^{z}\right)^{\top} \mid\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)\right]\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\leq} C_{1} \times p \times n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{k}\left(X_{i}\right)-\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right)\right\|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) by the i.i.d zero mean of the random vectors $\left\{\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}: i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ conditional on $\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)$ that holds by part (b) of Assumption 3.1, (2) holds since $\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}$ are not random conditional on $\left(W_{j}: j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}\right)$, and (3) by part (d) of Assumption 3.1 and Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)).

Using the previous derivations, it follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left(n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{z}\right)^{2}\right] & \leq E\left[C_{1} \times p \times n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{k}\left(X_{i}\right)-\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} C_{1} \times p \times E\left[\left\|\hat{\eta}_{k}\left(X_{i}\right)-\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} C n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}
\end{aligned}
$$

for some positive constant $C=C\left(p, C_{1}, M_{1}, M_{2}\right)$, where (1) holds since $\hat{\eta}_{k}\left(X_{i}\right)-\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right)$ are i.i.d. for $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$, and (2) by part 2 of Lemma C. 4 and (E-31), which defines the constant $C$. This completes the proof of step 1.
Step 2: Note that the maximum of $K$ positive number is bounded by their sum. Using this observation and (E-28), it follows (E-29).
Part 2: The proof of (C-4) is similar to the proof part 1. It follows from the following inequality:

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\max _{k=1, \ldots, K} n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}\right] & \leq E\left[\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{K}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}\right)\right] \\
& =K E\left[\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\leq K n^{-1 / 2} O\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}+1 / 2}\right)
$$

which goes to zero since $1 / 2<2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}$, and this is sufficient to prove (C-4) by using Markov's inequality.
Part 3: The proof of (C-5) follows from (C-3), by using $\partial_{\eta} m_{i}=\partial_{\eta} \psi^{b}-\theta_{0} \partial_{\eta} \psi^{a}$ and $\left|\theta_{0}\right| \leq$ $M_{1}^{1 / 4} / C_{0}$ (due to parts (a) and (c) of Assumptions 3.1 and (2.3)).
Part 4: The proof of (C-6) follows from (C-3) and (C-4) and the following inequality

$$
\left|n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}} \hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\psi_{i}^{a}\right| \leq n_{k}^{-1 / 2}\left|n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right)^{\top} \partial_{\eta} \psi_{i}^{s}\right|+C_{2} p n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}
$$

which holds due to Taylor expansion and mean valued theorem, part (e) of Assumption 3.1, and Loeves' inequality.

# E. 11 Proof of Lemma C. 4 

Proof. For $i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}$, denote $\Delta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{b}+\Delta_{i}^{l}$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{i}^{l}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{1}} n_{0}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} \delta_{n_{0}, j, i} \\
& \Delta_{i}^{b}=n_{0}^{-\varphi_{2}} n_{0}^{-1} \sum_{j \notin \mathcal{I}_{k}} b_{n_{0}, j, i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $\delta_{n_{0}, j, i}=\delta_{n_{0}}\left(W_{j}, X_{i}\right)$ and $b_{n_{0}, j, i}=b_{n_{0}}\left(X_{j}, X_{i}\right)$, and $\delta_{n_{0}}$ and $b_{n_{0}}$ are functions satisfying Assumption 3.2. In what follows, the results are proved for any given sequence $K$ that diverges to infinity as $n$ diverges to infinity, which is sufficient to guarantee the result of this lemma.
Part 1: By part (a) of Assumption 3.2,

$$
\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{l}+\Delta_{i}^{b}+n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \hat{R}_{i}
$$

and by Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)),

$$
\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{4} \leq 3^{3}\left(\left\|\Delta_{i}^{l}\right\|^{4}+\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{4}+\left\|n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{4}\right)
$$

Using the previous inequality, it follows

$$
n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{4} \leq 3^{3}\left(n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\Delta_{i}^{l}\right\|^{4}+n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{4}+n_{0}^{-8 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{4}\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} 3^{3}\left(O_{p}\left(n^{-4 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)+n_{0}^{-8 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|\hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{4}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} O_{p}\left(n^{-4 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by Markov's inequality and Lemma C.1, and (2) holds by part (d) of Assumption 3.2 and since $n_{0}=((K-1) / K) n$, which completes the proof of part 1.
Part 2: By part (a) of Assumption 3.2,

$$
\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}=\Delta_{i}^{l}+\Delta_{i}^{b}+n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} \hat{R}_{i}
$$

and by Loeve's inequality (Davidson (1994, Theorem 9.28)),

$$
\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2} \leq 3\left\|\Delta_{i}^{l}\right\|^{2}+3\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2}+3\left\|n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} \hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{2}
$$

Using the previous inequality, it follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[\left\|\hat{\eta}_{i}-\eta_{i}\right\|^{2}\right] & \leq 3 E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{l}\right\|^{2}\right]+3 E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{2}\right]+3 E\left[\left\|n_{0}^{-2 \varphi_{1}} \hat{R}_{i}\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} 3 E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{l}\right\|^{4}\right]^{1 / 2}+3 E\left[\left\|\Delta_{i}^{b}\right\|^{4}\right]^{1 / 2}+3 n_{0}^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}} O(1) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{=} O\left(n^{-2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds by Jensen's inequality and part (c) of Assumption 3.2, and (2) holds by Lemma C. 1 and since $n_{0}=((K-1) / K) n$. This completes the proof of part 2.
Part 3: It follows from parts 2 and Markov's inequality.
Part 4: It follows from part 2 and by using that $n^{1 / 2-\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}}=o(1)$.
Lemma E.1. Suppose Assumptions 3.1 and 3.2 hold. In addition, assume $K$ is such that $K \leq n, K \rightarrow \infty$ and $K / n^{\gamma} \rightarrow c \in[0,+\infty)$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

1. If $\gamma=1 / 2$, then

$$
\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right)-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1}=O_{p}(1)
$$

2. If $\gamma=1 / 2,1 / 4<\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}$ and $\varphi_{1} \leq 1 / 2$, then

$$
\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right)-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1}=O_{p}(1)
$$

3. If $\gamma=1$, then

$$
\left|n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1}=O_{p}(1)
$$

4. If $\gamma=1$ and $\varphi_{1}>1 / 4$, then

$$
\left|n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \hat{\eta}_{i}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1}=O_{p}(1)
$$

where $\eta_{i}=\eta_{0}\left(X_{i}\right), \hat{\eta}_{i}$ is as in (2.5), and $J_{0}=E\left[\psi^{a}\left(W_{i}, \eta_{i}\right)\right]$.
Proof. Part 1: Consider $M>1$ and the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P\left(\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \leq M\right) \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{=} P\left(\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \leq M\right)^{K} \\
& =P\left(1 / M \leq\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|\right)^{K} \\
& \geq P\left(1 / M \leq 1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right)^{K} \\
& =\left\{1-P\left(n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}<-(M-1) / M\right)\right\}^{K} \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\geq}\left\{1-P\left(\left|n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|>(M-1) / M\right)\right\}^{K} \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\geq}\left\{1-((M-1) / M)^{4} n_{k}^{-2} E\left[\left|n_{k}^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{4}\right]\right\}^{K} \\
& \stackrel{(4)}{\geq}\left\{1-((M-1) / M)^{4} n_{k}^{-2} 10 E\left[\left|\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{4}\right]\right\}^{K} \\
& \stackrel{(5)}{\geq} 1-((M-1) / M)^{4} n^{-2} K^{2} 10 E\left[\left|\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{4}\right] K \\
& \stackrel{(6)}{\geq} 1-n^{-2+3 / 2}\left(K n^{-1 / 2}\right)^{3}((M-1) / M)^{4} O(1) \\
& \stackrel{(7)}{\geq} 1-o(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

(1) holds since $\left\{\psi_{i}^{a}: 1 \leq i \leq n\right\}$ are i.i.d. random variables and because $\left\{\mathcal{I}_{k}: 1 \leq k \leq K\right\}$ defines a partition of $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, (2) holds since $M>1$, (3) holds by Markov's inequality, (4) holds since $\left\{\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}: i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}\right\}$ are zero mean i.i.d. random variables, (5) holds by Bernoulli's inequality, (6) holds by parts (a) and (c) of Assumption 3.1, and (7) holds since $K=O\left(n^{1 / 2}\right)$.

Part 2: Define the event $E_{n, \epsilon}=\left\{\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\psi_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}\right|<\epsilon\right\}$. Now, consider an small $\epsilon>0$ and $M>1$ such that $(1 / M+\epsilon)^{-1}>1$ and the following derivations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P\left(\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}+\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\psi_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \leq M\right) \\
& =P\left(\min _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}+\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\psi_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}\right| \geq 1 / M\right) \\
& \geq P\left(\min _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}+\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\psi_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}\right| \geq 1 / M, E_{n, \epsilon}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(1)}{\geq} P\left(\min _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right| \geq 1 / M+\epsilon, E_{n, \epsilon}\right) \\
& \geq P\left(\min _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right| \geq 1 / M+\epsilon\right)-P\left(E_{n, \epsilon}^{c}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\geq} P\left(\max _{k=1, \ldots, K}\left|1+n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|^{-1} \leq(1 / M+\epsilon)^{-1}\right)-o(1) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{\geq} 1-o(1)-o(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds because $\min _{k=1, \ldots, K}-\left|n_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{I}_{k}}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\psi_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}\right|>-\epsilon$ conditional on the event $E_{n, \epsilon}$ and triangular inequality, (2) holds since $P\left(E_{n, \epsilon}^{c}\right)=o(1)$ due to Lemma C. 3 (here I use $1 / 2<2 \min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}$ and $\varphi_{1} \leq 1 / 2$ ), and (3) holds by the same arguments presented in the proof of Part 1 by using $(1 / M+\epsilon)^{-1}$ instead of $M$; therefore, it is omitted.

Part 3: Consider $M>1$ and $\tilde{M}>1$ such that $\tilde{M}<((M-1) / M) n^{1 / 2}$ and the following derivations,

$$
P\left(\left|n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \psi_{i}^{a} / J_{0}\right|^{-1}>M\right)=P\left(\left|1+n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}\right|<1 / M\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \stackrel{(1)}{\leq} P\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}<-((M-1) / M) n^{1 / 2}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(2)}{\leq} P\left(n^{-1 / 2} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\psi_{i}^{a}-J_{0}\right) / J_{0}<-\tilde{M}\right) \\
& \stackrel{(3)}{=} \Phi\left(-\tilde{M} / \sigma_{a}\right)+o(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where (1) holds since $M>1$, (2) holds by definition of $\tilde{M}$, and (3) holds by CLT as $n \rightarrow \infty$ (here, $\sigma_{a}^{2}$ is as in (C-2)). To complete the proof, note that $\Phi\left(-\tilde{M} / \sigma_{a}\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $\tilde{M} \rightarrow \infty$.

Part 4: Define the event $E_{n, \epsilon}=\left\{\left|n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\hat{\psi}_{i}^{a}-\psi_{i}^{a}\right) / J_{0}\right|<\epsilon\right\}$. Now consider an small $\epsilon>0$ and $M>1$ such that $(1 / M+\epsilon)^{-1}>1$. Note that $P\left(E_{n, \epsilon}^{c}\right)=o(1)$ due to Lemma C. 2 (here I use $\min \left\{\varphi_{1}, \varphi_{2}\right\}>1 / 4$ ). The proof is completed by similar arguments presented in part 2 and part 3 ; therefore, it is omitted.

abstract:
This paper studies the properties of debiased machine learning (DML)
estimators under a novel asymptotic framework, offering insights for improving
the performance of these estimators in applications. DML is an estimation
method suited to economic models where the parameter of interest depends on
unknown nuisance functions that must be estimated. It requires weaker
conditions than previous methods while still ensuring standard asymptotic
properties. Existing theoretical results do not distinguish between two
alternative versions of DML estimators, DML1 and DML2. Under a new asymptotic
framework, this paper demonstrates that DML2 asymptotically dominates DML1 in
terms of bias and mean squared error, formalizing a previous conjecture based
on simulation results regarding their relative performance. Additionally, this
paper provides guidance for improving the performance of DML2 in applications.
